149616231.review:
[h1]Overall = 9/10[/h1]

Another brilliant production with superbly detailed graphics, a powerfully emotive story and beautiful, well placed music.  The story is very good with plenty of surprises and quirky humour and although it does have plenty of the love story clichés, the writing elevates it above the norm.  However, I don’t think video games are the right medium to tell these types of story –there’s very little game play, it’s linear with no replay value and Act II is just linear storytelling.  The time loop beginning was fun but there’s no puzzles to solve within it and it felt as though there should have been more required to progress the core plot.

148819126.review:
Good interactive point/click visual novel that ties in with other stories of the developer, namely To The Moon and Finding Paradise.

While similar to the other games of the series, Impostor Factory does stands out on its own and is a good story independently if you have played the other games.

As with other games of the series, Impostor Factory is 2D with graphics and movement giving out that GBA era vibe, with fairly good music and sound effects, and with a story that is well written, to the point, and manages to be quite cheesy at times, and sad at others.

Only issue for me, as it was on the other games of the series, is that it is on the short side, given the price, and left me craving me for more.

Overall a very good read. 7/10

148470723.review:
After just finishing this game and reading the reviews, I would very much agree that this is:
A.) Walking simulator.
B.) Not the best one.
C.) Great Storytelling.
D.) All the above.

It's D. It had to be. No contest. And to all of the complaints, I agree. But I simply don't care. This series thrives because of it's storytelling. Kan Reeves Gao could write another ten more of these and I would gladly scarf them up. He is great at creating compelling characters that suck you in until you are simply dying at the end of an act for the next scene. It's marvelous and makes me wish I could write such realism. 

However, I would say that if I had to pick, To The Moon would be my favorite one. This was the Space Trilogy's "That Hideous Strength" to the series. Not the best, but could not be complete without it.

Mr. Gao, my hats off to you. Well done.

148306381.review:
[h1] A Solid Conclusion [/h1] 

Much like Freebird's previous games in this series, Impostor Factory takes you on a touching and emotional story through a person's life, but this one has a bit of a twist in the way that it is structured. This difference is interesting and for the most part well done, although it does feel a little overwritten at times, especially in the third act. Without going into spoilers, Impostor Factor's story sticks out to me as the most emotional, and probably best written of the series so far. There's some moments in this game that really had me tearing up. The writing here is absolutely superb in the second act and this is where the game shines. The third act is a bit all over the place since it tries do a lot, and at times it can feel a bit of a mess but it manages to still pull off a satisfying and heartfelt ending. The pixel graphics are beautifully done as are all of the games by Freebird, but it really stood out to me this game. They really fit the tone of this game much better then previous ones I think due to the horror feeling that parts of this game fall under. If you enjoyed the previous games in this series then you'll love Impostor Factory as it is very much more of the same. If you haven't played the previous games I highly recommend playing them before this one as a big part of this story relies on previous knowledge to be effective. For more reviews, follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40795588/] curator page. [/url]

Do check out Freebird's other games as they are all fantastic, beautiful and touching in their own ways.

146430997.review:
TLDR: Impostor Factory is a solid continuation to “To the Moon'' saga, and I would highly recommend it for all fans of the series.

The game tells its story this time using mostly a different set of characters, but it does a good job extending the world established by the two prequels. (That being said, the prequels should definitely be played before this one to get the most of the story).
As a person who enjoys stories of the sad nature, I appreciated the plot and general feel of the game a lot. Like with the prequels, the story was highly engaging with its mysteries and twists, and the emotional payoff is definitely there at the end.
The gameplay is even more simplistic than before, but in my opinion it only improves with the pacing of the storytelling - you are probably here for the story and feels anyway.
A shout out for the soundtrack is also in order - the music is what really makes some of the emotional moments even more impactful.

146247670.review:
Freebird Games never fails. Another beautiful, emotional, hilarious story.


[[SPOILERS BELOW!!]]




I will say,  however, even though I enjoyed the game, it did not have the same impact To the Moon and Finding Paradise did, and got a little bit too confusing towards the end. I feel like, unlike the other characters like Johnny/River, and Colin/Faye/and his wife, Quincy/Lynri, while a beautiful start (i loved the act two story). their story kinda got less emotional in the third act. The idea of Lynri losing the baby and completely removing Quincy from her life was heartbreaking, and a huge part of me thought that we were experiencing one of the first scientist who created Sigmund Corp rewriting their own memories (Lynri rewriting her leaving Colin after the baby died, and essentially writing the ending of the story as her new memory). 

I do like that we finally got some insight on Neil, and why he uses the machine, and what could possibly be wrong with his, but i do wish act two held more weight bc that was very interesting, but act two was pretty much shut down by the finale, which made it kinda obsolete imo.

I am reccomended this game because i do not think it is a bad game, and those who love Freenird games would still enjoy it, however, this is a game you DEFINITELY have to play after To the Moon and Finding Paradise, especially if you're invested in the story of Neil.

145887881.review:
I just have to say that this developer became one of my IMMEDIATE favorites. The price tag is well justified and I would encourage anyone who likes a great story to jump on this one - and the others (To The Moon, Finding Paradise, A Bird Story) IMMEDIATELY. This is a series you NEED in your library.

The thing that makes these titles so special is the fact that they're very thoughtful and have complicated storylines, and they run the gamut of content - from light and funny, to dark and serious, to hopeful, heart-broken, upset, happy, and everything in between. This series is one of those that when you start one of the games, you just won't be able to stop until it's finished, and each one has a lot of content/story. Once you start playing, you'll be gripped by it and just HAVE to know how things turn out.. and you'll probably sit there playing until it's done. AMAZING, AMAZING stories.

Basic concept (which, I don't think this will be a spoiler, but I'll hide it anyway): [spoiler] Ever had something you know you're going to regret on your deathbed? Maybe you wish you had done this thing, or made that choice. Now your life is over, and you're regretting how things turned out. What if there was a way to truly believe you HAD done that thing or made that choice? The company Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene work at does just that - on your deathbed, they burrow into your memories, find out what makes you tick, and implant a series of new memories into your head - overwriting the old memories - so that as you pass away, you do so happy with the way things turn out.[/spoiler]

The great thing about each story is diving into it, figuring out what makes each character tick, finding out all about them... and it's told in such an amazing way. I can't tell you enough how fantastic this developer is at telling stories.

My recommendation is to play them in order. While each episode is a "self-contained" episode, it really benefits the player to play them in order. Kinda like how if you watch different episodes of your favorite TV show... sure, each show might be a self-contained story, but you don't get the full context unless you watch them in order.

To The Moon
Finding Paradise
A Bird Story
Imposter Factory

Some folks might disagree and say A Bird Story should come before Finding Paradise, since it sorta comes chronologically before FP... But one of the things that makes each story great is "getting to know" the people involved... and I feel like "A Bird Story" is better viewed as the "deleted scenes" of a movie, rather than as a prequel. If you watch the deleted scenes on a DVD first, maybe it won't "spoil" the movie, but it just doesn't feel right. Play FP first, and then dive a little deeper with ABS.

Get all 4 of these immediately. This is one of the few storyline games that got me a little choked up. I absolutely LOVE the characters and every bit of these stories was phenomenal. I couldn't possibly recommend them any more. They are well worth the full price. I had... SO much fun, and I am ANXIOUSLY awaiting the next chapters from this developer. STUNNING story. Easy gameplay. VERY... very moving.

145217976.review:
i will try to keep this relatively spoiler free, but no promises during my little ramblings

its not exactly necessary to play To The Moon and Finding Paradise to play Impostor Factory, however i recommend at least playing FP; some elements of the game come back to IF and then the whole story just wont hit the same without that context

i have heard that some people critisised the game for being something else, and different from the other two games, or just plain said 'yeah, this is good, but the previous titles are better'. yes, it is different, but i find its a good thing! this was truly something else, a whole new unique experience. it made me cry; not the little tearing up i did during Finding Paradise, but full on bawling. maybe partially because i jumped into this one without letting myself process the other two games, but i dont care. still cried real tears. which is unusual for me! i dont cry! but this game's themes kicked my butt while i was down. it carved my heart out and folded it into a little origami rabbit. it looked me in the eyes and reminded me just how short and precious life is

quincy, the seemingly new protagonist, is the funniest game character i have ever encountered, and his reactions feel so authentic, unlike with Neil and Eva, who hide behind a mask of professional apathy, he shows his feelings and reacts humanly (and hilariously) to the stuff put in front of him. and the animation, oh the animation! its so good???? i loved Finding Paradise's little animated cutscenes, but this is something else. cant find such high quality pixel art in many places. and the opening credits, hmmmmmmmmm. the way the game's initials, I F, appeared before the rest of the title; because this is ultimately a 'what if?' its an exploration of a possible world, worlds, entire lifetimes

the story, like already said, has stolen my breath away. i so want to sit down with the creators and just. talk. thank them for this experience. i am staring at a wall in misery as you read this. its an easy recommendation. playing the other two games before this one may set up the bar for this title a little high, but i still like IF. its clear the creators experimented with pretty much everything with this one, and i for one think it payed off

this is more than a time loop murder mystery. so much more.
also there is a really long cat in there

144111565.review:
Impostor Factory is another great experience from Freebird Games, the studio behind To the Moon and Finding Paradise, two titles I highly recommend for their amazing storytelling.
Like them, this isn’t exactly a game, as it plays more similarly to a visual novel, but with a different, pixelated style and without significant story branches.
However, the story unfolds a bit differently. It deviates from the other two titles, where you play as a pair of doctors trying to rearrange a dying patient's memories to fulfill a wish inside their mind.
It’s different, but not necessarily for the best. It’s more of a mystery, where you try to figure out what is happening as you go along. The story has a lot of twists and turns, as well as many emotional moments.
The story is also amazing; however, I’m not a big fan of some of the reveals. Contrary to the game’s F.A.Q on the Steam Store, you should definitely play To the Moon and Finding Paradise before Impostor Factory. Otherwise, you’ll miss the connections, especially towards the end of the game, and the impact won’t be the same.
Also, I overall preferred those two titles, so I recommend playing them first anyway. This one is still a great title and another easy recommendation; it’s just that the previous titles may have set the bar a little too high, and this one takes some risks by deviating from what we were used to, instead of playing safe.

144046005.review: I went into this completely blind, not expecting much, and it ended up being one of the greatest things I've witnessed all year. Set aside ~4 hours for yourself and just play this now, please.

143991875.review:
this game is not a murder mystery thriller, it is a sci-fi and romance (but honestly mainly romance) sequel to a different game.
the description repeats the fact that you can play this game without having played the others from this creator, but that is really not the case. they go through all the effort of introducing two characters and making them fall in love only to pull the plug at the end and make it all about some other couple who are apparently their kids??? not that the story of quincy and lynri is that good in the first place- okay i guess if you like romantic stories about life and scrapbook-like beautiful memories and a bit of bitterweetness then this might be the game for you. but the reason i bought this game is because it marketed itself as a time-looping murder mystery, which it is not at all. it starts out like that but the mystery is dropped after its introduction to go on about the romance. either way lynri reveals that its all a simulation anyway so theres no more intrigue and you just go along with the rest of the story because they got you with the hook. they loop back around to it in the end with this tense suspense because lynri suspects something bad is going on with her memory machine but then this angel??? with tentacles???? breaks the machine???? and also the earth???? so really the game does not try at all to deliver on the mystery, instead it seems to get bored and start to shoehorn in a fluffy lovey plotline. they also show the life and growing up sequence of lynri so many times with only slight changes it really made me bored. i left this game feeling confused and wondering if i had accidentally launched the wrong game because it really was not what i was expecting. some people might find this game to be a pleasant surprise but some people like me will not. 
a lot of the positive reviews on here are from fans of the creator which is great. but this game did not make me want to play the other games.

143567684.review:
Impostor Factory. The third (fourth if you count Bird Story) installment in the To The Moon series by Freebird Games, and games that have come to emotionally dominate me. They're really simple - mostly walk and talk simulators, and I noticed that the puzzles at the end of the memories were gone in this installment (not that they were particularly hard). 

And let me tell you when the game says the story isn't about Neil Watts and Eva Rosalene from the first couple games, they mean it. The [spoiler]real world versions of them only show up after the credits have rolled. Even then Eva only really says a couple lines in this game.[/spoiler] We focus instead of Quincy Reynard, who's invited to a mansion for a social gathering but gets way more than he's bargaining for - and meets a mysterious girl named Lynri. 

The game didn't make me cry like To The Moon and Finding Paradise, which I was sort of disappointed about as it was the reason I was holding off on it for so long, but it was still plenty heartbreaking. [spoiler]In our reality, Lynri chose to save Neil (who's implied to have a condition of his own) at the cost of her living a long healthy life. In the reality the game shows us through the memory walk, Lynri lives long but Neil (Tobi) passes away and she leaves Quincy and lives out the rest of her life at the Foundation who invented the technology we're familiar with.[/spoiler] Lots of complicated character moments, but in the end I love how Freebird Games always tells really compelling love stories. 

Here's to the Beach Episode!

142314957.review:
I’ve read a lot of comments about people feeling underwhelmed by this came in comparison. I just wanted to express my praise for this game. 
To the moon made me feel a dissonant joy at seeing the old man’s fulfillment of what could have been, but sorrow in that it wasn’t real. The was joy in his long life with his love, but sadness in the unfairness of his situation and irony. 

Finding paradise gave me curiosity and wonder and pure fulfillment in seeing the man’s happiness and contentment in living life out exactly as it happened. Realizing in his last moments that the “regrets” he had in life didn’t take away from the happy life he built with his family, but rather were a part of it. And he got to say goodbye to his guardian Angel in Faye. 

Now, in Imposter Factory, I also felt joy and melancholy irony. I felt happiness and bitter sadness. But I also felt a WIDE spectrum of other emotions on a deep scale. I felt anger at Lynri for leaving Quincey. I felt joy at seeing her fall in love at the university (where I met my wife) delight in seeing her raise Tobi and soul crushing despair when he passed away. I felt curiosity in the manor. I felt nostalgia and hope seeing Faye. I felt unease in the ending with Neil. In all, I felt more variety of emotions in this game than the prior two, and feel it is my current favorite of the franchise for that reason. And least favorite because it made me want to hug my baby toddler and never let go.

Too many similarities to my own real life that just gave me even bigger feels than the other games gave me.

If you are looking for something quick and action packed- this isn't the game for you.
If you are looking for something with BIG feels, or you have played the other games in the series that came before- get it.

Yes, some of the story is fantastical. But there are people out there who have faced some of the situations and choices in the game, and either had to or chose to make them.

I found it entirely too relatable because of my own life history and story. I will likely never play it again, because it cut deep in some places. But I am glad I did play it in one sitting this one time.

YMMV.

I think this will help you appreciate the game's setting and topics it touches upon more. 

This is probably my favourite entry out of the series so far, it strikes a significantly way better balance between humour, heartwarming and drama compared to the previous games. It's best to not approach it as a murder mystery, though, but as a tale of love.

141836785.review:
Genuine dissapointment and easily the worst story out of the "series". (Marked spoilers below.)

Impostor Factory has a giant flaw. Ironically, it's a hollow "impostor" of previous stories. Tries to go for the same story beats, yet is predicatable, going nowhere and worst of all, completly pointless. There is no point in investing yourself in the characters, because [spoiler]beside the epilogue, none of them are real[/spoiler], no point in following the story, because [spoiler]multiple realities, everything is a simulation, etc.[/spoiler], no point in pretending that anything actually matters. The "emotional moments" are like something out of a bad soap opera and, again, they don't matter in any way because see above. 
What offended me the most, tho, was the part in the epilogue, where one of the characters tries to slightly "lampshade" the fact, that what we saw was kinda of a nothing. Yep, you just spent 5 hours, to see a guy [spoiler]make himself a bit happier after seeing his mother's memories? Or maybe sort out those memories of his parents? Or rather imagine his parents and himself being happy for once? Who knows? Maybe he had a little too much spare time?[/spoiler] It doesn't work like in the previous titles, because that character is FULLY AWARE of what is happening?? So everything that happend during the game is just kinda brushed aside at the very end??? Okay. You can call it out as pointless, but it doesn't change the fact that the story WAS pointless.
Another random tidbit, that iritated me, which might be controversial, but reviews, like opinions are highly personal: [spoiler]Did the story imply, that putting the unborn baby's health over your own is the "correct" choice?[/spoiler] Seeing as everything that happens before it is supposed to be kinda awful, but after the change everything is more or less fine and dandy (and more "canon"). That's something that I definitely cannot get behind.

After excellent To the Moon, and slightly worse, but still great Finding Paradise we get this. What a shame.

You know that ugly cry? That cry you have so deep that it hurts? I did that. Got a headache and it ruined the rest of my day. 10/10 would ugly cry again. 

But in all seriousness, Freebird Games just keeps outdoing themselves with each game. That said, Imposter Factory is probably the least accessible of the games. You really need to have played To the Moon, A Bird Story and Finding Paradise to really enjoy this game where I feel To The Moon, and even Finding Paradise to a degree, much more of standalone experiences. 

Without actually dissecting the story, the game deals with the concept of choices - what it means to live each moment of your life to the fullest. Do you live for each moment and cherish it because it will never come again or do you dedicate your entire existence to bettering the world than they way you came into it? You may think you know how you feel, but this game may have you think twice about your own life in the most surprising ways.

The games self-depreciating and culture (meme) humor is on full display here, too, but done far better than in their previous titles and in just enough quantity to give you a good chuckle between the darker and sadder moments in the story. 

I cried,. I laughed. And I cried a hole lot more. What more can you want from Freebird Games?

139982627.review:
From the creators of To The Moon and Finding Paradise, so you know how this works. You take your little 16-bit sprite character through a story of laughter and heartstring tugging, a journey that will make you laugh and cry. And oh boy, what a great start this game has. You show up to a party where there's a bunch of investors for a project of some sort and then a murder happens, and there's a mysterious woman, and you go back in time, and a bunch of crazy things happen. The first act of this story is PHENOMENAL. I laughed several times, I gasped in surprise, I openly remarked to my wife in the other room "This game is so pugging great!" It's amazing. And honestly, I recommend exiting the game right there and basking in how good the first act was.

But if you didn't do that, that's too bad, because now you have to go through the second act. The above mystery woman, who you had a handful of conversations and have barely gotten to know suddenly thinks you find her interesting enough to set you on a journey witnessing her ENTIRE PUGGING LIFE STORY, and folks, it is a trope-laden, cliched, dismally boring slog. She was born with an illness of some sort (never fully explained) which sets her as The Doomed Girl. She meets a fellow student who is a Free Spirit but apparently not free-spirited or interesting enough to have any sort of life outside of being a good boyfriend. You will run through every major moment in their lives together along with way too many minor ones, with a progress bar telling you how much longer you'll need to keep going through this mind-numbing journey of two cardboard cutouts in a story so bland that whatever AI program was involved in writing it probably requested a pseudonym. I quit after almost three hours of gameplay because I stopped caring and wanted to do anything other than spend time with these characters for one second more.

This game rates as Overwhelmingly Positive on Steam and to you Yes voters, I am Overwhelmingly Positive you all are lying. Maybe there's a third act that is a breathtaking work of staggering genius, and maybe the AirBNB that's surrounded by five miles of foul-smelling sewage has a nice pool. It doesn't matter, I'm never gonna get there.

139917526.review: Probably my favorite of the three, honestly! 139806453.review:
This was the email I sent Freebird Games after this game came out. There are some light spoilers.

"I often wondered about whether games could really, truly change someone's life - make someone reflect on their life decisions, or help them clarify some of their thoughts about themselves or the world around them. I've played many games, some with great emotional impact or that were really fun experiences that brought me joy. But this one, Impostor Factory, this was one of the only ones that really changed me. That changed my life.

When I played Finding Paradise, I cried at the end - Colin's obssession with the imaginary was something I found quite relatable. I thought that was the peak of what games could do for me, as at the time I was somewhat of a colder person. I enjoyed the game, called it a masterpiece, and moved on.

Then four years later, Impostor Factory came along. I was now a different person, at a different mood and with different emotions. I was grappling with my own insecurities and fears of what the future would look like for me. I was clinging to the idea that I would live my life focusing on one single objective, and kind of ignore everything else, including relationships, to pursue that goal.

So when that conversation between Quincy and Lynri, about their different viewpoints on how life should be lived, occurred... something clicked with me. I began thinking more and more about this concept - Lavenders and Stars - and really question whether I really wanted to beeline myself into one single goal.

My time here is limited, and I didn't want to leave without leaving a mark, as a 'mediocre' person. But at the same time, I realized... I don't want to be alone. I realized I was masking my fear of coming out to my parents with the idea that I didn't want relationships, and as such would never have to discuss such things with them. I felt trapped and alone, but I didn't want to admit it. I had built up this totem of "Relationships are dumb and I'm above them" for so long that I couldn't question it anymore. It became almost a dogma.

After all of that (and some conversations with some of my friends), I decided to come out to my mom. For eight years I knew I liked boys, but I never could muster the courage to tell it to her until now. At the end of the conversation, she hugged me and said that I should've said it much earlier, and that she would always support me. If I hadn't played this game and hadn't had those conversations, perhaps I would've just decided to go on with my life without telling her anything. Would I be a happy person? Perhaps, perhaps not. But without a doubt, this freed me from my cage.

So, yeah. Sorry for the wall of the text, and thanks again. I feel so much lighter than before, and your game really helped me with that. Your games are awesome."

135885640.review:
Kan, you made me cry... again! I swear you're getting some kind of kick out of this!

As part 3 in the To the Moon series, you get exactly what you expect... with a little twist. It is mostly the exact same thing (for all the good reasons) but it tries to vary it structure this time around and it works wonders for the game.

Playing the previous parts in the series is definitly required, this is the most lore heavy entry in the series and reaplaying them beforehand would have probably been a good decision on my end. Admitedly, this makes the third act of the plot a bit confusing and it has a hard tonal shift that I'm not sure if I like. However this would be just more of the same if it wouldn't have done it, and you can tell this game reaches for more than the last two.

I also want to mention that I don't think these stories could ever be told in a different format or a different genre. Kan Gao and his team fully understand the medium game and the engine/artstyle they're using, and they have mastered that to the fullest. There is a reason why these games are so popular and that is that there are probably no other games like it, that have managed to tell a story with such excelence in worldbuilding, character drama and location design.

A special shoutout once again to the incredible soundtrack. Whilst I don't recall a specific outstanding track this time around, it knows exactly when it wants to activate your waterfalls, and it does so in annoyingly effective fashion once again.

Usually when smaller creators suddenly create a franchise, a smash hit, and find themselves in a position of more money and more power, it gets to their head. And most franchises shouldn't have even made it past the first sequel. We are 4 games (and some bonus stuff) in right now, and I don't ever want it to stop. This is one of the most competently handled IPs out there right now, and I applaud everyone who has worked on it!

Idea for the next sequel: To the Moon... but with a 2. Think about it, just think about it...

135809379.review:
Impostor Factory, the third major game in the To The Moon universe, is an interesting mix of different storytelling approaches. Its first Act is a weird, darkly funny whodunit case with serious hints at time travel. The second Act is the story of our protagonists, up to a pivotal point in their lives, with one of Kan Gao's usual beautifully told, heart-wrenching human dilemmas. Then Act 3 tries to wrap up everything, science fiction style.
The first two acts are about perfect in their own genres, but I feel the third one falls short - it certainly failed to keep my interest, and at some point, it even took away from the drama of Act 2. Plus, as usual, there is not much game in the game, we're mostly walking around barely interacting, and the game takes care of the storytelling. This was OK in the super engaging first two acts, but it was additional hardship in #3.
In the end, as all ambitious undertakings, Impostor Factory is not perfect, but it's a distinct, memorable game with strong values. Certainly recommended.

Regarding negative reviews, before you take stock in any of them keep in mind this game is the 3rd of a series and was advertised as such, so without playing the first two you're jumping into a series mid-way i.e. if you only watched Return of the Jedi you'd not be shocked that Vader is Luke's father and Leia is his sisters (spoiler alert for a 30 year old movie)

(short version)
A well written visual novel that strongly supports the previous versions, absolutely worth the price especially if you're a fan.  

(long version)
With that aside, yet another amazing game written by freebird.  This is a fully text based game and there aren't the previous puzzles to solve which might upset some, but for me it wasn't a big deal.  The writers are very good at what they do and kept me engaged throughout the whole story.  The music is fantastic and gets you when it needs to and just like previous games I had to choke back a tear or two as I went on. 

Now secretly I am hoping they do not release a 4th one because this wraps the story up with a very nice bow leaving just enough to the individual to fill in the blanks on their own.

133846160.review:
Impostor Factory (this game came out in 2021, that name CANNOT have been a mistake) is the third entry in the "To the Moon" series, or the Sigmund Saga. Despite some people being mislead by the description, It is effectively required that you play the two previous games in order to understand a significant portion of what's going on in this game.

Out of the three games, all of which I adored, this game hit the hardest by far. Not only in the context of the series, but in general. This may be due to my relating strongly to certain events that have taken place in my life. No game has made me get as actively invested, angry, emotional, and fulfilled at the end of its story. While the first two games create the premise, and then ask and answer some important questions regarding the premise, this one ties both together and answers some things very nicely in what may be the most beautiful way that I can think of.

I would say that if you're going to play just one of these brilliant games you should play this one, but that would entirely destroy the point of the story. I've read far too many reviews about people being confused after having not played "To the Moon" and "Finding Paradise." Please play these two games BEFORE this game.

133013793.review:
There are several reviews which indicate they prefer the first two entries in the series over this one. Having completed the game myself now, I can understand why, although I disagree with any implication that the first two games are subsequently superior in story quality to this game.

This story feels like a mix of Cthulhu, Inception, and To The Moon. The mystery/horror elements are especially prevalent in the first act so I can see how this might startle fans that are expecting the same safe sad-but-feel-good story across all acts like in To The Moon and Finding Paradise, with maybe a touch of creepiness which Watts' sense of humor usually downplays. It certainly did not start off in the way I was expecting. Creatively I feel like it was trying to take a different approach to what was starting to turn into a formula developed for an episodic series and I found it refreshing. 

It can be convoluted at points (I am including Inception on the story trope reference list for a reason), but the explanations hold and I enjoyed the experience throughout. The writing is still just as emotional and hopeful as the other entries. The qualities which made the other game stories so appealing are still there, including it's humor and dialogue beats. [spoiler]Ricebot is everything. Please give me rice. I want to taste the world's best rice.[/spoiler]

Kan Gao's composition makes a triumphant return for this game as well. Overall I hope that the developers will continue working on the series to provide a conclusive ending within a main game, since Eva and Neil's story is still ongoing and they only had minor appearances this time around.

EDIT: I noticed at the time of writing this review that I beat the game in less than 4 hours. It absolutely feels longer than 4 hours. There is a lot of emotional content in there.

133011595.review: Free Bird Games does it again with this fantastic narrative. I personally think this is my favorite out of all their games so far because the story behind it is a bit more simple but has so many great tie-ins to previous games (which you don't technically need to know before playing). I ugly cried maybe 3 or 4 times during my gameplay and absolutely loved learning about the main characters and their story. There was a good balance of comedy, slice of life, drama, romance, and everything you'd want in a narrative-based game. The ending was beautiful, and it was especially great if you've played the previous games before. I strongly recommend this to anybody that's on the fence about buying and to anybody that enjoys games that pull at your heartstrings. 10/10.

132495436.review:
Impostor Factory is the 3rd and final entry in the To The Moon Series, for now. Unlike the previous two titles, this one follows the story of new characters and the creation of the memory machine that Sigmund Corp. uses. While the story doesn't follow our beloved characters of Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene they still have a role to play, just as a minor role this time around. 

The story this time around follows Quincy. Quincy arrives at a high-class party but doesn't quite understand why he's there. Unfortunately for Quincy the evening takes a quick turn when the hosts end up dead. Understandably Quincy freaks out a bit and ends up in the bathroom. Washing his hands however, seems to reset the entire evening. This is the beginning of an odd case of clue, in which the same people die and no one knows who's killing them. After a few resets, Quincy believes that he may have come across a lead when he sees one attendant has a duplicate self. Pursuing this lead begins the start of a long heartfelt slope into history. 

Unlike the previous titles in the series, this game doesn't use puzzles, and instead is primarily a walking simulator that provides answers to questions from previous titles, and leaves some open. It is not required to play the previous games to play this one, but I would highly recommend you do. The game does still utilize memory orbs like the previous games, these orbs are earned through interacting with environments or by witnessing events. This is the extent of any puzzles in the game. 

While the game did tend to be a shorter title, the information delivered was both intriguing and heartbreaking upon realizing what it meant. Just as you think you finally know exactly where the story is going, something happens to counteract that. Eventually, this no longer works but despite knowing what's to come what happens and is inevitable still holds impact. Not every story requires multiple twists and turns, nor does it require that its secrets remain hidden until the very end. Often, the best stories will give you the answer early on, and maybe not in the correct sequential order. These stories are the ones that still provide impact, draw the player into their world, and leave a mark on those willing to see it through to the end. That is exactly what this series has done for me, and I eagerly await the studios next work. It may take a fair bit of time, but quality cannot be rushed, and I would rather wait years for an impactful story than six months for something I'll forget.

Imposter Factory is the 3rd mainline entry in the "To The Moon" series of games.
All in all, it's a simple story told effectively with lots of touching moments.
In terms of gameplay, it's practically identical to previous entries, that is to say - there is very little of it. You pretty much just watch the story unfold, with little to no intervention in how. There were no surprises there as far as I was concerned.
The plot, surprisingly, has almost nothing to do with the story of the previous installments. I can say that for me that wasn't something I was particularly happy about, but it did allow certain surprises which I won't spoil to hit more effectively.
I will say, however, that as a result it can be played standalone without issue.
This game is fairly short, I believe even shorter than the previous entries in the series.

If you're a fan of the "To The Moon" series, this game will hit most of the marks you've come to expect and will therefore be enjoyable for you. Otherwise, I'm not sure that the simple story, short playtime, and lack of meaningful game mechanics would grip you enough.

130603996.review:
"Ken Gao doesn't miss. 5/5"

After completing To The Moon & Finding Paradise, I was ecstatic for the next instalment in this series. So when I started Impostor Factory, I was confused as to how the game started and its premise. Upon reaching the end, it became clear why this story was told in the way it was. For those looking for a rich narrative, and wonderful character development, this is the game for you. *YOU MUST PLAY TO THE MOON & FINDING PARADISE BEFORE PLAYING IMPOSTOR FACTORY* My review ends here but below I go in further depth as to why this game received a perfect score from me (Spoiler Free); 

STORY
The narrative within this series is the primary focus to why these games are so good, and Impostor Factory is no stranger to this statement. Impostor Factory tells the story of innocent, upbeat, lovable Quincy as he receives an invitation to a dinner party. Entering, he is equally perplexed as he is astonished upon the establishment he has entered. As the evening progresses, a shocking turn of events unfold and as the player you are IMMEDIATELY immersed. Joining forces with another guest, it is your job to figure out what exactly is going on here, but is everything really as it seems...?

GG's (Gameplay and Graphics)
This game has been developed by RPG Maker, so in terms of game-play mechanics, its as basic as it comes. You can move around and interact with npc's and the environment, however the main appeal here is the narrative and the music, both masterfully executed. The graphics are presented in the same common RPG Maker pallet, however the fantastic use of colours, saturation, and lighting utilised my Freebird Games encapsulate the themes, settings, and establishes the narrative your heart will fall for. Graphics are very accessible here as you can make the image to your liking via the options menu. 

MUSIC
Last but certainly not least, the score in the series carry the emotions of the narrative. Every plot point, every sequence, the music perfectly encapsulates the themes presented and truly makes you feel for the characters and their emotions. Music is a very powerful tool for expression, and the composer here does such a fantastic job. Can definitely admit I've cried many times during each session and as the story progressed.

Despite this, the plot was engaging from start to finish, and the twist at the end was well-done, even though I had anticipated it. 130165345.review:
Wow. They did it. They FINALLY made a good game in this series! I wasn't expecting to like it, but they managed to make an engaging narrative driven game that kept me interested from beginning to end! It's still a tour through set pieces, but it wasn't boring or repetitive like the other games. It broke the mold and did something NEW, something INTERESTING, something I actually WANTED to keep playing! Even if it doesn't have a lot of replay value, it's still such a good game that you have to play it at least one time and experience the journey. I seriously recommend buying this and playing it for yourself. You don't even need to play the other games to enjoy this one. It's a great experience all on its own!

But, to go into further detail...

SPOILERS, THIS IS A SUMMARY OF WHAT HAPPENS IN THE GAME; 
YOU SHOULD PLAY IT FIRST AND THEN READ THE REST.

This game serves as an origin story for the Sigmund Corp. and for Dr. Neil Watts. 

His mother, Lynri, was diagnosed with a hereditary disease with unpredictable patterns as a little girl. When she went to college, she met a man named Quincy. They debated over whether they enjoyed their lives or stuck with their careers. After graduating, they got married and made a compromise: Lynri would work for a group of scientists who created a prototype of the memory simulating machine, while Quince would be a stay-at-home husband. However, the machine ended up killing one of her colleagues during an experiment, causing her to leave her job and travel the world with Quince. When they came home, they found out she was pregnant with Neil.

But the pregnancy was difficult. Lynri found that her disease was in the early stages of altering her physical well-being and shortening her life expectancy. The treatment for the disease would've given Neil birth defects, so they chose to deliver him healthy and THEN undergo the treatment. The problem was they started too late, and the disease had its effects on her.

Lynri went back to Sigmund Corp., the company who licensed and improved the technology after the accident, to have her memories archived for Neil.

Neil grew up as a healthy boy, but Lynri soon died. After being diagnosed as an adult with the same disease, he decided to take her place and pursue the same career. At Sigmund Corp., the technology was perfected, leading to the events of the previous games in the series.

His secret project was building a memory simulating machine that would let him access his mother's memories. He also uploaded a digital copy of Faye, Collin's imaginary friend from the last game, to help him with the process. The game is essentially simulations of Quincy and Lynri going through altered versions of her memories to stabilize the archived memories so Neil could see and keep them for himself.

The only problem is that the machine is running so many different copies of Quincy, Lynri, and her memories that the digital world they inhabit will soon collapse. Faye takes them out of the digital world and destroys it, but she's also able to give them an award. Since the latest copy of the simulation is the closest to Lynri's archived memories, Faye can send them through a portal so they can live the "perfect timeline", one where the family didn't have any issues with hereditary diseases, treatments, or Lynri's death, and they get their happy ending. 

One minor problem I have is that it's not ENTIRELY believable (Neil loving Eva was pushing it too far), but it was still nice to see Neil give his parents a good life and better memories before shutting down the machine and keeping the archived memories.

This is easily the most interesting story in the series. It kept me guessing what would happen next, and I found the cast of characters to be more likable and interesting than ANYONE in the Sigmund Corp. It also made Neil a sympathetic character, one that I came to like for who he is internally, and what he was trying to achieve the whole time.

It also helps that the gameplay actually changes things up and doesn't get repetitive or boring. It's still a tour through set pieces, and they occasionally have you gathering memory links and bringing them to a memento; but it's made a lot shorter and easier to find everything and move on to the next segment; and, more importantly, I legitimately enjoyed THIS tour through THESE set pieces. 

This journey through Lynri's simulated memories was far more emotional, interesting, and left a greater impact than either of the patients from the other games. I actually cared about what was happening to Neil's family, and I wanted to see how it would end.

Freebird Games finally won me over with "Impossible Factory", and I'm legitimately excited to see where the series goes next!

I feel as though talking about anything regarding this game could end up being a spoiler, so I won't go into detail. I will say that this really felt like a game for us- the players of the series. Though it's like that not so much in the sense that it picks up perfectly where the last game left off (Apparently this takes place right after the previous game), but more so that the story really resonates with you should you have the experience of the previous games under your belt.

Other than that though, this is still an excellent entry in the Free Bird portfolio. As expected of them the pixel art is fantastic (So many new sprites!), the overall art direction was on point, the writing was wonderfully engaging, and the music was gorgeous. My only complaint in these areas was that there were very few times that the playable character had anything to say when interacting with the environment, and those are usually some of my favorite interactions. That, and in the beginning of the game there were some times that the writing felt witty for the sake of being witty, rather than being what a normal person would actually say, but maybe that makes sense with the context of the end of the game 

Bottom line- if you've played Finding Paradise and To The Moon (Which you should, if not why are you here?), this is another solid entry. You won't regret the ~4 hours you'll spend on it. It didn't make me cry nearly as hard as the previous games, but not every good experience needs to be sad now does it?

125714353.review:
This review will be broken into two sections: A quick and dirty guide on whether or not you should pick this game up, and then a more detailed evaluation of the game for nerds like myself who enjoy words.

First, the quick guide:

[b] Did you enjoy To the Moon and Finding Paradise? [/b] Great, buy Impostor Factory. You may not love it as much as the previous games, but you will enjoy it. However, I strongly suggest you replay Finding Paradise before you pick this one up. Trust me, it will help you later!

[b] Have you never touched To the Moon or Finding Paradise? [/b] Okay, then go play those games. Please start with To the Moon. After that, play Finding Paradise. If you end up liking those games, then pick up Impostor Factory. Despite what the Steam description says, you should [b] NOT [/b] play this game without having experienced the other two games. The significance of Impostor Factory’s final act will be lost on you without the context of the previous games.

That’s it the for the quick review. A more detailed review and some minor structural spoilers lies ahead. Nothing major in terms of moment-to-moment plot points will be discussed, but turn around now if you want to go in completely blind.

To put it bluntly, I feel as if Impostor Factory has something of an identity crisis.

The first section of the game presents itself as a murder mystery. The tone in these opening moments is striking when compared against To the Moon or Finding Paradise. You’re not a doctor trudging through the memories of a dying patient anymore. There is a very real and immediate sense of danger seeping through the mansion, and it is [i] lovely [/i] to play through. Quincy does not have the previous weird-world experience mastered by Neil or Eva. He is very much afraid and unequipped to handle the strange situations that he finds himself in, and it is an absolute joy to help him unravel the secrets of the mansion. You never quite feel safe, and you’ll be dying to know what happens next.

However, for better or worse, the game begins to shift at the midway point. Without slipping too deep into spoiler territory, the story eventually drifts into something that is much more reminiscent of the previous games. The tension is deflated, cast away as if it had never been there at all. Likewise, the then-current items of conflict are unceremoniously put on hold in favor of the usual melodrama that Freebird is known for.

And while that melodrama may be interesting, it isn't consistent either. Towards the end of the game, the story’s focus shifts once more. What comes next is, for lack of a better word, surreal. The game’s tries to hit you with a curveball, but the pitch just doesn’t find its mark. Your millage may vary, but I can’t help but feel as if Freebird just did not know how to close the story.

With this being the case, Impostor Factory left me disappointed. The story raises many questions, but it dares to leave half of them unanswered or floundering with half-baked resolutions. The more I sit with story, the more I feel as if Freebird just did not know what type of game they wanted to make. A murder mystery? A heart-felt, down to earth drama? The rambling dreams of a surrealist? There are so many interesting ideas on display, but they just don't have the focus needed to properly develop. 

Impostor Factory is my least favorite entry in the series, but the game isn't awful. Wasted potential, maybe, but by no means is it a waste of your time. Even if the story isn’t perfect, many of its big moments are still very, very good. The series appears to be building towards something bigger, and I am definitely interested in seeing where Freebird takes the story next. My one hope is that they'll settle on a consistent plotline next time.

Either way, set aside about four hours for yourself to play the game. If you are able to do so, I suggest playing through the game in one shot / session; I feel like that's the best way to experience Impostor Factory. While the story may not tug on the same heartstrings that To the Moon did, you will most definitely walk away with a memorable experience.

125502248.review:
To summarise: The plot has a lot of emotion, but there's no interaction whatsoever. You'll walk in a straight line for 3 hours, with minimal choices as you do, and little commentary. Sadly, you gain nothing from being the one playing the game, you could get by watching a no-commentary playthrough and have the same experience as everyone else in the reviews. (i.e. following Act 1, you'll just be pressing the W key and reading.)

Having played all the of the predecessors of this series, I can confidentially that this instalment is odd. The game starts off on a very different note then it ends, and the contrast in themes/gameplay gave me mild whiplash. The first act was excellent, and the mystery element was really, really engaging, but the later acts became a lot more dense. The art has improved greatly, but I found myself asking, "Okay, so when does the prologue end/when does the game start?" multiple times. (Maybe I'm heartless, but I didn't really feel moved by a lot of what I was reading--it wanted to be relatable but felt more fantastical. I think To The Moon was far easier to resonate with.)

What got me is that there's no game. No choices, minimal object interaction, little exploration. Don't let the first act fool you, 90% of the later acts is holding down W while your character walks down a path. It's just a long flashback that could have been summarized into a 2-minute segment of any other game. I don't see the point in recommending this, when you could easily get the same emotional-trip by watching someone else play it silently. You won't be missing anything, I promise.

125409035.review:
Definitely a stepping stone to the next (hopefully the final since the wait is killing me) iteration in the series, but a lot of stuff to ponder about here. 

Analysis
______

The multiverse's existential implications considering that each layer could have been activated by a different entity than Lynria, however some iterations of the last layer making the result similar to the first layer (and Lyndia/Quincy actually discovering Faye because of that, and even then moving on to relive a "perfect" considered life by Faye) gives Steins;Gate vibes but on a much grander scale.

There were also similar motifs as the first game where the stars affecting the lavender could be compared to the moon, but on a deeper look, their reasons are very different. One is for fulfilling dreams in a limited life, and the other is for discovering a complement. Comparing how basic elements of nature interact with each other and juxtaposing that with human emotions has always been the developer's speciality, and I can't wait to play their future games in this series.

Also, it is shown that Neil has feelings for Eva (or at least deeply cares for her). This is amplified by the fact that they were married in the perfect life envisioned by him.. 

Narrative 11/10

124806125.review:
If you played To The Moon, you know there is only one question worth asking about Impostor Factory. But we'll come to that later.

If you haven't, there are three.

Question one is: what kind of games are Kan Gao's To The Moon and Impostor Factory? They are interactive fiction in the style of old 16 bits adventure games. Don't expect challenge here. There is none. Don't expect choices. There are few. You're along for the ride. And what a ride it is.

Question two is: what makes them special? A knack at telling very human stories about life and love and making the best of what time there is. A bit messy sometimes, and sometimes tragic. And what human things aren't?

Question three is: do you need to have played To The Moon before playing Impostor Factory? [i]YES. Do not believe anyone who tells you otherwise.[/i] They're part of an ongoing set of works, and Impostor Factory builds onto To The Moon in important ways that would be criminal to spoil.

But if you've played To The Moon, you already know all that. You're only wondering: after all this time, does Kan Gao have new things to say?

Yes.

Go in blind. Find out why on your own.

I thought the series had no tears left to wring out of me. Goes to show what I know.

Yes, the game pulls a bait and switch that would make a used car salesperson cry tears of joy, but truthfully once the first big reveal happens, the game stops being a game. 119548176.review:
An ambitious title that is very different from the previous entries in the series.

It's very good, but a bit of a let-down compared to the previous two major instalments in the series (To the Moon and Finding Paradise). Impostor Factory on the whole is a pretty good game with an engaging storyline, but isn't as direct or relatable as the previous two games. This story gets its value in the writing twists as opposed to emotional breakthrough moments, but the writing is still very good.

The graphics and writing excel in this game compared to the previous games. The scenery and characters are excellent and there are a lot of very nice little details: In one scene at an airport, there's a person at the bottom of the screen with their phone charging in the wall. The music is fitting and enjoyable, but I didn't enjoy it as much as To the Moon or Finding Paradise.

I would say the promise of Impostor Factory being "bonkers" and "categorically out of its mind" are about right. The details of the story are abstract and confusing at times, which might make the game worth playing a second time. But as the story relies on twists and shock moments, replay value is much more limited compared to the previous two games - I've replayed To the Moon a few times and still love it. I don't know if I could play Impostor Factory more than twice without it losing the charm. On the first playthrough though many of the moments in the story are memorable, if not just a different tone than that of the previous games.

A pretty good game, but different.

118725552.review:
Definitely made me cry, just like all of FreeBird's games.  Absolutely loved the experience by the end of it.  

It has some issues that I think are worth talking about.  As much as I loved it by the end, some of the story's choices make it lag in places.  SPOILERS AHEAD!

Act 1 introduces a fun, almost sci-fi themed murder mystery with a mysterious woman, time travel, and lots and lots of dead bodies.  But, Act 2 all of the sudden thrusts us into an entirely different story about a young woman battling a hereditary condition that gets married and tries to find purpose.  So, essentially, the game promises a murder mystery and then forgoes that for a drama.  While Act 2 does provide us a somber, yet hopeful viewing into someone's life that can be very beautiful - it feels disappointing next to the interesting sci-fi murder mystery.

Now, Act 3 does bring it ALL together.  And I personally really enjoyed Act 3.  Ricebot is the best.  Long cat will never be forgotten.  There are some things that are revealed that really make your head spin (in the best way in my opinion).

By the end, I loved it.  But, the journey to getting to that can laboring.  I think for some people, Act 2 can be beautiful. 
It discusses life, death, purpose, etc. and can really hit home for some.  I'm sure the experience for this game is going to be different across the board.  For me personally, I wish Act 2 could have been condensed or could have had more going on.  For example, I would have liked to see long cat throughout the game as our main character's companion so he can have someone to talk to about everything he's seeing.  Having fun interactions between their characters would have helped the story a lot.  Because he only says a few words for 2 hour span of Act 2 and I wanted to hear him talk.

Overall, loved the game a lot.  I came out of crying my eyes and feeling intensely philosophical.  It may have some issues, but I enjoyed the experience overall and would recommend it for anyone who's a fan of the "To the Moon" storyline.

How to explain... When I first watched the trailer, I was really concerned. This did not look at all like To the Moon or Finding Paradise. After completing the game, I can confirm that if you want another game like the first two, you're in luck. A wonderful emotional story awaits you. I can also confirm that the trailer is pretty much accurate. How those two are both true is a bit of a mystery, but it works. If you enjoyed the other games in this series, you'll enjoy this I have no doubt.

The music is wonderful as always. The game-play is definitely refined. To be fair, the worst aspect of To the Moon was the tedious searching for enough colourful balls to move to the next scene, then solving a picture puzzle. Finding Paradise made things a little better, but Impostor Factory takes the cake. This game does away with the puzzle, and the colourful balls come to you as you experience the story, so it plays much more fluidly, and you won't be stuck in one scene for far longer than was intended.

As stated in the game's description, you can play this game independently of the others. I will say (without spoiling anything) that there are a couple of moments that would have no real impact if you hadn't played the previous games, whereas the impact they had on me was significant. So my recommendation would definitely be to play the other games first.

So yeah, highly recommended. If you're at a loss after watching the trailer and reading the description, good! I can only say that that is the correct way to approach this game. Now play it, and all will become clear.

117838553.review:
SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW

This game was very frustrating to me. I never played the other two games in the series, so maybe that had something to do with the bad experience I had with the game. This game has no gameplay. There is like 1 puzzle you have to solve at the beginning, but after that it is just walking and cutscenes. This game can be easily split into three parts. The first part was probably the most fun I had with the game, as it was more or less true to the promises that the steam description gave it. It was a time loop murder mystery game, and frankly that was somewhat enjoyable. About an hour or so into the game, you go through a random door, and are transported to what I can only call the worst excuse for a section of a video game I've ever had the displeasure of playing. It is a more or less 2 hour hallway that you traverse down and interact with balls that play cutscenes that reveal the life of one of the (at this point) random NPCs that are in the mansion. This section goes on for way too long, and frankly if there was any gameplay in it, maybe I would have found it enjoyable, but it was just a movie that I had to babysit. After this long slog, that really only kinda matters, you get to act 3. Act 3 is really "cool" because it basically invalidates Act 1, and just kinda throws whatever at the wall and hopes that it will stick. Turns out the mansion is a simulation, you're not a real person, and there's something messing up the timeline. This sounds cool, because oh it's a murder mystery again, but no, turns out the villain is just a character that was never introduced before, alludes to vague simulation stack overflow essentially, and you get more or less the same cutscenes from act 2, but you are on the roof of the mansion. MAYBE I would have enjoyed this game if I had some knowledge of the previous ones, but the lack of gameplay, questionable controller support, and overall just boring (in my opinion) story ultimately just killed my interest in it. The art and music are pretty good tho.

117328257.review:
First of all: this is not a standalone game. If you have not played To the Moon or Finding Paradise (and all the other games?) you will not understand the significance of a lot of the ending.

I've played the previous two games, but so long ago that I could barely remember the overarching lore. I'm not sure that To The Moon really needs an overarching plot. Small, episodic games centered on human stories would have been enough. But it especially didn't need [i]this[/i] game, that starts with an interesting premise that gets dumped fairly early on just to give you the origin story of one of the characters in the previous games.

And that's essentially what this game is: an origin story for one of the To The Moon characters. You might be moved by some of what happens, although it's all meaningless in the end as we rehash the idea of what makes something real or not. And like the previous games, we end up following a romance between two straight characters where one of them has some form of insurmountable problem. I honestly was hoping the romance was a fake-out, or a missed opportunity, because it was so cliched. Quincy was basically a manic pixie dream boy with no real personality. 

It's honestly a shame, because I did want to solve a time looping murder mystery, and that was the most interesting part of the game. In the end, there was no mystery at all, just a trip through grief town and long exposition about the world's "lore."

116073345.review:
[h1]A mix of comedy-horror slapstick and weighty emotional story that bloody works[/h1]

Impostor Factory… The third entry of the running series by Freebird Games; a company that left a lasting impression by releasing To The Moon, a game that’s famous for its breathtaking storytelling and beautiful soundtrack that brings the best out of each scene. Since then, superb story writing is something synonymous with this company. This time, they took a slightly different approach to the story’s theme. While it’s not as emotionally compelling as the previous entry, I find Impostor Factory to be one of the most enjoyable story-driven games I’ve played recently. 

[h2][b]Now, about the game[/b] [/h2]
[b] In a nutshell, the reasons I’m particularly fond of Impostor Factory were that: [/b]
[list]
    [*] Superb story writing – as expected of Freebird games, they always deliver
    [*] Can be played independently without clearing the previous entries
    [*] Simple yet rewarding gameplay
    [*] Brilliant soundtrack that complements each scene
    [*] Sentient rice cooker that cooks godly rice and long cat that protecc
[/list]
[h3]Classic RPG opener[/h3]
I mentioned before that Impostor Factory is the third entry of the series. Now, you might think that you have to play the previous entries to understand the story, but fret not! While it’s somewhat a sequel, Impostor Factory is a standalone experience that rewards both new and long-time followers of the series with its weighty emotional story and sci-fi plot that relate to the other entries.

The story kicks off with Quincy, our main character, arriving at a fancy party in the middle of nowhere. Being told that he was the first one to arrive and feeling out of place, he decided to take a look around the mansion where he met a fellow guest, Lynri, on the second floor of the mansion; this confused him as he was told that he was the first one to arrive. The party progressed and everything was fine until Quincy discovered that the host was brutally murdered. But that’s not all, things started to get even weirder as the corpse suddenly vanished, leaving no trace whatsoever. That event left Quincy in a panic state to the point that he suspects even the household cat as a potential killer, which makes me laugh at how ridiculous it was. Strange things are happening and everything is not how it seems to be. What happens next is horror-comedy slapstick with Quincy at its center.

I have to mention that despite Impostor Factory being a 16-bit game, everything is beautifully illustrated, from the huge mansion in the middle of nowhere to the lush lavender field. In addition, the characters had a detailed design and smooth animation. You can see the amount of love and effort poured into this, big props to Freebird Games.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813216850 
[h3]Simple and straightforward gameplay[/h3]
Gameplay-wise, I think there aren’t that many changes from the previous entries. Impostor Factory uses the classic RPG exploration mechanic: you explore the area to find hidden orbs that would allow progression to the next area. Now, I know that gathering hidden objects tended to be tedious in older RPGs, but not in this one. As you look for these orbs, you’ll find glimpses of memories that show you the tale of Quincy, which made the gathering feel a lot less tedious and more rewarding since you get to know his backstory in the process.

I tend to explore every room before moving on to the next area, especially on classic RPGs like this, and Impostor Factory is what I call a short game. Including the exploration part, it took me close to six hours to completely clear it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813219259 
[h3]Beautiful soundtrack[/h3]
Freebird Game once again proved themselves as a genius not only in writing up brilliant stories but also in composing beautiful soundtracks. They did it so exceptionally well that you can feel how the character felt at that given moment. It lightens the vibe during a comedy scene, hypes you up during a thriller scene, and best of all, it brings the emotional scene to the next level. All in all, the soundtrack did a perfect job in delivering a wonderful experience and is definitely on my playlist now.

[h2][b]Overall[/b][/h2]
Ever since I finished To The Moon a few years ago, I got completely hooked on the series. So far, none of the entries have disappointed me, including this one. Even with its simple gameplay, Freebird Game manages to create yet another gem. The best thing about Impostor Factory was the quality of the story writing; they successfully made it hilarious and profound at the same time. While It’s slightly lacking compared to the previous entries, Impostor Factory is still a great read and I truly enjoyed playing through it. For those who are looking for a good narrative, I highly recommend you give Impostor Factory a shot. Even when it’s not on sale, it’s absolutely worth every penny, especially if you’re planning to get into the To The Moon series.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2813216861

114524504.review:
(NO SPOILERS)
It really pains me to write a negative review for one of Kan Gao's games but here we are. Let's get a few things out of the way first: the OST? Amazing as usual. The graphics? It's the usual pixel art but even better. The characters? Complex and with an interesting story to tell... but yeah, the two main characters' story is what really disappointed me. If you're into the whole Sigmund Corp. drama that's been going on since To the Moon then yes, play this game. But if you're like me and play these games for the "two main characters plot" that starts and ends all in the same game then no... it's kind of a huge disappointment here.

(SPOILERS)
I really enjoyed act one and almost cried a few times during act two. But then the game basically tells you that nothing is real and everything is just a simulation. Yep, those weren't the real Quincy and Lynri, just an alternative version of them. As soon as the game said this I lost most of the connection I had with them and simply stopped caring. As I've already said, I almost cried a few times during act two but act three and its ending didn't make me feel anything. I was just staring at the screen thinking that if life really is a simulation and nothing is real then I should've spent these four hours doing something better... like playing Finding Paradise. 
I do realize that this review is very subjective, so if you enjoyed the game... good for you! I'm glad you didn't end up feeling like you wasted your money like I did.

114434700.review: As with To the Moon and Finding Paradise, the entire reason for playing these games are for the stories they provide. Although feeling a little short, I really appreciated the emotional impact of the writing as well as how it neatly tied the series together in an interesting way. After playing the previous titles, I wholly expected some kind of mental deep-dive into someone's past but I wasn't expecting the way everything delightfully connected here. At this point, if you enjoyed the previous entries in this series then I don't believe you'll feel let down by Imposter Factory. Adversely, if you haven't played any of these games and you're coming across this one for the first time, I urge you to pick up all three and play the entire series as a whole. I hope this series continues because I'm already yearning for more.

112883823.review: Another masterpiece after To The Moon and Finding Paradise. Incredibly well-written story, characters, great music and gorgeous artwork keep you glued to the screen for about 4-5 hours. The type of story is definitely something new compared to the previous entries in the To The Moon-saga, but as it progresses it's revealed as a logical next chapter. The pacing is much better than the previous two, because there's fewer forced gameplay elements in there and it makes for a beter flowing story. I have to say that I was sobbing uncontrollably with To The Moon and Finding Paradise at the end of each game, Impostor Factory did not hit me as had in the end. That is hardly criticism, though, as several emotional scenes brought tears to my eyes all throughout the story this time around. Again, the writing is on par with what came before, and maybe even surpasses it in terms of realism. I'm looking forward to whatever Freebird does in the future, as I always have ever since To The Moon surprised me the first of many times I've played it. Kan, you thank us for sticking with you through the years, but allow me to thank you and the wonderful people you collaborated with to make these masterful stories happen in a way that makes the videogame world even brighter and richer than it already was.

111352381.review:
[h1] Summary and Review [/h1]

[b][i]Impostor Factory[/i] is a game that portraits the life of a couple, how they meet and the challenges they have to face along the road with certain ethical dilemmas included, during their (short) “lives” – Memento Mori. [/b]

The story shows that not everything in life is as black and white as we perhaps hope it to be, shit does happen and people make mistakes, but in doing so the story manages to successfully capture a ‘slice of life’, to which in my opinion the player can greatly relate on a sentimental level.

Overall a well written story and unique ‘overlapping’ way how the player gets to experience this.

I do want to point out that as this series progresses with these (more or less) individual stories (that still connect with each other), it becomes increasingly more a story the player gets to [i]only[/i] and quite literally ‘walk through’ while watching + reading, rather than it being a game with any challenges or exploration options. This in contrast to, for example, [i]To The Moon[/i], where there were also parts like Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene getting to ride a horse, or explore a part of the fair – which I especially liked because it also had a ‘surprising’ element to it without breaking storyline or being too challenging.

111341988.review:
I wish there was a middle ground between recommend or not, because I am so ambivalent on this game.
It's labeled as the 3rd entry of the main games, but it honestly feels like a side-story. 

This time around, we play as Quincy instead of Dr Watts and Dr Rosalene. Playing as just one character, meant that there was a whole lot less banter between characters, but Quincy himself doesn't have a whole lot of things to comment on. He merely observes and stays silent for a good chunk of the game.
There's no puzzles either, which limits the amount of things you can interact with which in turn gives you less flavour-text/character notes/interactions. 
Overall, it felt a lot more like a walking simulator than To The Moon and Finding Paradise.

The music, while good, felt like a step down from the earlier games. Nothing was as memorable as the other two games. Tracks like "For River" and "Faye's Theme" are just much more memorable to me.

Act 1 of this game hooked me quite well. There was a sense of mystery, there were characters to interact with, Quincy had a lot of internal monologue and it was great. Then act 2 kicked off, and Quincy just too a backseat. You're basically just walking to the right and getting exposition along the way, while our dear main character stays silent for the majority of the act.
The game's story does handle some delicate themes which it handles in a great way, and at some parts, my emotions did show a little bit. But in no way did it feel as emotional as the previous games. I just didn't resonate as much with the characters this time around.

Also, while the steam page says "Impostor Factory can be played independently, just like the games before it.", which is just a lie, when you take the last part of act 3 and the epilogue into account.

Overall, I think I was a little let down by this game, and after writing out my thoughts, I think I'm gonna go with "not recommended", BUT if you have played the other games, and want more, you could go play this. Maybe buy it when it goes on sale or something.

Fortunately, good folks there also recommend [b] To The Moon [/b]. I played and finished all these game in 3 days, and I must say that it was a wonderful journey. The writing is superb and the music is very phenomenal. There were some issues with the older game, but it was just very minor compared to overall experience in playing this game. These three games are the good games that make you reflecting your life and asking yourself questions about life. 

The storytelling in this game is exceptional, you can feel the sadness, laugh awkwardly at the dry humor, feel proud for the character's achievement, and even roll your eyes at some jokes. The story is one of the strongest point of these three games, I highly recommend you to play this game without any walkthrough or read spoiler to enjoy the game to maximum level. 

The music in this game is truly phenomenal it deserved a special paragraph in this review. I regrets that I only played [b] Impostor Factory [/b] using my headset. If you have a proper headset or headphone, try playing these games using your headset/headphone to appreciate the music. Do you still want to hear the music after finishing this game? Do yourself a favor, all the soundtracks are in Spotify for you to stream.

Try these games. Totally recommended.

I wanted to add another positive review and have more people find FreeBird games since they are great stories.
