Also these are story-based games so there's little gameplay. However the stories are strong enough to keep me going back to them. I'm planning on playing all three games all at once and see how this connects to the other two. 

I love this developer studio for creating such heartwarming and emotional stories. In some ways they are so relatable in the character's struggles and how life throws curve balls that change peoples' goals. I cherish these games and wish people to experience these wonderful stories.

109904875.review:
Muchas veces se realizan críticas que, en mi opinión, son injustas a la hora de juzgar un videojuego. Quien realiza un juego tiene un objetivo en mente. FromSoftware realiza un juego con miras en ofrecer un sistema de combate pulido hasta el más mínimo detalle. Por otro lado, cualquier juego de Telltale Games tiene la intención de ponerte en la piel de un personaje, y tomar decisiones que dirigirán el rumbo de tu historia. Criticar a Telltale Games por tener un combate aburrido, o a FromSoftware por no emocionarte con su historia, serian críticas, en mi opinión, injustas. 
Por eso mismo creo que esta saga de tres videojuegos hechos por Freebird Games es perfecta. Desarrollaron sus juegos con la intención de contar una historia. No se propusieron que cada jugador viva su propia historia, y por eso no tiene sentido que haya decisiones. Detener el guion seria cortar la fluidez de la narrativa, y por eso no tiene sentido que haya combate. Los recuerdos son preciadas posesiones para las personas, por eso tiene sentido que hayan decidido “Encriptarlos” y darle al jugador la tarea de desencriptarlos mediante mini juegos en forma de puzles. 
En mi opinión, lo que hace a un juego bueno, es que se proponga un objetivo (O más de uno) y lo cumpla. Esta saga de juegos se propone una única cosa, y es contar una historia emocionante. Y sin dudas, emocionan hasta las lágrimas todos sus juegos. Por eso, sin dudas para mí, son excelentes juegos los tres, y muy recomendables.

109431108.review:
Impostor Factory is not a bad game. It's also not a great game, unfortunately. It pains me to say that, because I've waited for it ever since it was announced and literally counted hours until the official launch to play it immediately once it was out. I even gave myself weeks, which then turned into months, to digest the game and mull it over before forming any final thoughts, because i hoped i'd change my mind. A lot of people are very positive about this game and i felt my experience was an outlier of some sort. This review is partly for people who also had a similar experience and partly for me to accept that this game didnt live up to my expectations.

First of all, i have to say, i felt and still kinda feel lied to by this game's marketing. It is being sold as a murder mystery but it is not one. It [i]appears[/i] to be one at the start, i'll give it that. However, the mystery gets basically explained to the player with their minimal input.

Speaking of that, the simple puzzle segments and interactions with the environment are gone. I do have to say, it felt as if the world was much more empty because of it, but perhaps that was the point. That doesn't change the fact that their absence was very much felt. I've seen many people complain about how this is basically a walking sim now but the To The Moon series was always kinda in the walking sim genre, besides the genre itself is not a bad thing. I always thought that these games were more about the story than the gameplay, honestly.

The thing is, the story is not very good in my opition. Going forward i'll be discussing some story elements in detail so [b]Heavy Spoiler Warning[/b]. Also this is obviously just my personal opinion and i'm a biased being.

I feel that, contrary to most negative reviews i've seen, i'm one of the few people who didn't like the game but ended up liking Lynri as a character. Even before I got to play, i was already immensely excited about finally getting what i presumed to be a female patient for Neil and Eva (oh how naive i was back then!). The thing is - i like Lynri as a character. I don't really like the story she's in though. While playing through her flashbacks i was excited to see that she was her own character and seemed to be all about leaving a legacy behind, which seemed to be majorly motivated by her unspecified disease. I liked that as her drive! She seemed ambitious and i was curious to see what she would face.

Then we meet the flashback Quincy. I feel like i'm gonna be in the very small minority here when i say that i Really [i]Really[/i] dislike him as a character. Don't get me wrong, i loved seeing his friendship with Lynri develop, i was actually very excited about the possibility of them staying strictly platonic friends. And then my hopes were squandered. I know that the TTM series kinda has a formula of being focused around characters who have families and love lives and romance is always a part of the story, but with how much Impostor Factory was changing up things i hoped that the story wouldn't be so... tried. Not only that, but Quincy gets rejected and still [i]Insists[/i] on getting together with Lynri even when she says no the first time.

Quincy introduces the conflict of domestic bliss vs successful career which i very much dislike. There were several scenes showing the player that Lynri was focusing more on her work than on the relationship and it was portrayed negatively, while i was sitting there going ????? because ???? of course this would happen???? She specifically stated that she won't be able to balance her personal life and work when rejecting Quincy and [i]he[/i] was the one who insisted on going out even if that was the case, i honestly don't know what he expected. 

Another thing that irks me is that after the travelling montage it seems that Lynri never gets to try to find a new fullfilling job ever again. She is immediately pregnant and then later on has to make a choice between her own life or the baby's. I'm gonna be honest, this story beat made it too "pro-life" to comfort for me. Especially since the choice to choose her life ends up being framed as the bad and selfish one. I could write entire paragraphs on how women in the TTM series are mostly only mothers or love interests and how disappointed i was to find out that even in a game about her we mostly experience everything from the perspective of her lover and she's not allowed to exist on her own but instead ends up being Neil's mother as a twist. I really dislike the fact that in the timeline where she chooses herself she ends up being completely miserable.

The whole simulation thing just made it look really unnecessarily complicated and honestly felt like this whole ordeal was kinda meaningless in the end. I didn't really feel anything during the ending, which i think is just... kinda sad, considering the other games in the series. It's very ironic that i enjoyed the dlc comic way more than the game itself (then, to be fair, the comic was mostly about the doctors and i enjoy them the most in those games).

By all accounts, Impostor Factory is not a bad game. The visuals are beautiful and the music is fantastic. It just ended up being not a game for me, personally. Maybe i ended up overthinking it, maybe i misinterpreted some events, i don't know. I wish i was part of the majority who seems to love the game and says its perfect, but that wasn't my experience.

I hate to give this thumbs down, but I just couldn't help but feel let down after playing it. I played all of the Freebird Games to date and loved every one of them. This one just didn't feel as special as the previous ones.

I'm also disappointed by the format - this is the third entry in the series (fourth if you count "A Bird Story") and I'd like to see some innovation in the gameplay - after all, it's a video game. I feel there was none of that, and this game, more than the previous ones, could just as well be a movie. If there are no interesting optional interactions, secrets or branching paths and the gameplay is just walking and talking to characters, then moving around (or player agency in general) becomes tedious. In "To The Moon" you at least had some different, more "video-gamey" segments. Here, I just wished I could speed-up the "gameplay" sections and move to dialogues and story.

To the Moon felt special and I loved it. Impostor Factory is not bad - it's just not that special and I feel that it does nothing to be special, except an emotional story - which is good, but I feel that's it's just not enough this time.

107376619.review: Another masterpiece by Freebird Games. I laughed. I cried. At one point both at the same time. (My cat looked at me strangely.)

107363761.review:
It feels weird to downvote a game I think was so well-made, but here I am. Just finished this game and I'm disappointed. Before I start, I went into this having never played any other games by this studio, I think playing their other games first is a good idea before playing this.

That out of the way, this game was two glaring issues, both related to each other. The first is that the gameplay changes completely. It starts as a point and click adventure then totally changes in act 2 to a walking simulator visual novel. The second is the pacing, as Act 2 utterly destroys all the buildup and intrigue from act 1. You go from a murder mystery to an extremely long flashback of a side character's entire life. I have never seen a game squander a good first act so poorly. Imagine if you were playing a Resident Evil game where after you beat the first boss, the entire rest of the game is just unskippable cutscenes of Barry's trials and tribulations going through adolescence, getting bullied, losing his grandpa, being inspired by to win a spelling bee, and losing his virginity.

Now, that being said, I think that as a visual novel, act 2 is a good story with good writing. The issue really is just that it is such a jarring shift that left me feeling totally unsatisfied, as I kept asking myself "Why the hell am I watching the life story of this person who had barely any screen time in act 1? Why would I want to watch this after act 1?"

I also was pretty confused and unsatisfied by the ending, because [spoiler] I came into this under the impression this was a standalone game, and questioned why the game was expecting me to care about Neil or his wife/gf who I knew absolutely nothing about since I hadn't played any other game in the series. It felt so weird that I picked up on it being fanservice. It fell totally flat for me and really ruined the ending. If your whole ending is gonna be devoted to being fanservice for previous games in the series, be more open about it having a definitive place in this whole series in the game's description. Not having played the prior games severely hampered my enjoyment of the ending. [/spoiler]

Ultimately, I just want people reading this to be aware that most of this game is just watching cutscenes and reading dialogue and not solving a murder mystery in a time loop, which was not my expectation from the promotional materials.

107151363.review:
[h1]Is this actually a reality taken from one's mind, or a fabrication?[/h1]

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] The next chapter in the Sigmund Corp Series, this title barely features it.  It maintains the art & comedic style of the previous titles, but is completely disconnected from the main story until the very end.  Regardless, it still feels resonate to the rest of the series, focusing on regrets, memories, & the idea of adjusting past mistakes in one's own fantasy.  A rather sudden & wonderfully confusing 1st act kicks in that leaves the the main character, Quincy, to begin questioning everything around him.  It, along with the music, draws the player in for another ride of a story, leading to an eventual heartwarming/heartbreaking climax, depending on the player's point of view.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] Once again, all of the same problems, but with a neat little twist.  The 1st act is a mystery that feels like it ends a bit too quickly, & the 2nd act plods along.  The 3rd act is about what one would come to expect from this series.  A noticeable take away is definitely the lack of a Laura Shigihara song at the end.  That's about all one can give, considering how similar the Sigmund Corp Series games tend to be.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENT[/u]:[/b] Another one for completing the story.  Another simple, several hour trail to completion.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] Impostor Factory feels more interested in pulling in new players compared to the previous title, but it's still very similar.  These games are good, emotionally resonant, but are simply stories.  If you enjoyed the previous titles in this series, then you will enjoy this.  If you were curious or cautious about the series, & for some reason haven't tried To The Moon, then this may be a decent starting point before going back to the rest.  If you didn't like To The Moon or Finding Paradise, then this game won't sway you.

107137562.review:
Great writing as expected from Kan Gao! If you're looking for a game of the mystery thriller genre, not too sure if this is the game for you. It's sorta part of the premise but I can't go into too much detail without spoiling the plot. Trust me when I say it's mostly heart-warming like the previous games and if you haven't played To the Moon and Finding Paradise (grab A Bird Story while you're at it if you can), then you'll be missing out on a lot of the plot elements so I definitely don't recommend you playing this game before at least finishing To the Moon. 

Besides that, the dialogue between the characters made it really personable especially with the struggles I'm facing as a working adult and growing older. They felt very real to me in that regard and that's what made me love the characters a whole lot. 

The removal of the memento puzzle segments made the experience more immersive as well (less hindrances to the story) however, I think there's a missed opportunity to have more "point-and-click" puzzle sections which would've made it more interactive though I guess it depends on the developer's ability to implement such puzzles in a thought-provoking manner with the setting of the To the Moon games. From what I remember of Kan's previous game titled "The Mirror Lied", there's definitely potential to develop this area.

Overall, though it didn't make me bawl like a baby,I think Impostor Factory might be my favourite episode of the 3 games that have been released! Cheers to another job well done Freebird Games! XD Lookin' forward to your next game!

Impostor Factory, the third in line of the To the Moon series, is a rather different story unlike To the Moon and Finding Paradise. Personally, it doesn't feel as personal and bittersweet as the previous two has, but compensates with a rather different story altogether.

Impostor Factory does have the soundtrack and visuals going along together, a funny moment or two — a staple of Freebird Games productions —, and the story is still pretty good. However, I didn't really resonate with the latter as much as I had done the previous two episodes of the series. It does have a heart-warming moment or two, but doesn't really pull it off as much as the previous episodes.

Nonetheless though, it's a reasonable addition to the series, and [spoiler]the twist at the end definitely is an unexpected one[/spoiler]. Even though it (slightly) under-delivers, I still enjoyed the game and would recommend it!

106525414.review:
TLDR: Imposter Factory's pretty good. It builds upon the previous two games in the series in some ways, but in other ways it struggles. Overall, it's still an enjoyable experience if you liked the previous games. If you didn't like To the Moon or FInding Paradise, however, this may not be your cup of tea.

For starters, Ken Gao and the rest of the devs at Freebird did a great job with the graphics. Considering the fact that they're using RPG Maker and are such a small studio, it's really impressive what they pulled off. It is abundantly clear that they have learned over the years, which is made apparent by looking at the progressive improvements in the graphics from To the Moon, to Finding Paradise, and finally Imposter Factory.

The music in this game is alright. It's certainly not bad, but I'd say its predecessors had more memorable OSTs. Unlike the previous games, I don't remember the tunes or names of any of the tracks in this game. By no means is the soundtrack bad, it's just not as memorable as To the Moon's or Finding Paradise's in my opinion.

As for gameplay, it hasn't changed much. They completely removed the puzzles in between levels, which I believe they did in Finding Paradise but it still bears mentioning. The devs also removed the little scavenger hunts for the items to unlock the memories. In my opinion, this was a good change because they didn't do much other than pad out the game time for no real reason. However, due to this, there isn't much gameplay other than walking and interacting with characters/objects. If you find that type of gameplay boring, you may not enjoy this very much.

Finally, the story was alright. If you're worried about spoilers, I'd skip this paragraph. It wasn't as captivating, climactic, or emotional as the other two games to me personally. Similar to my point about the music, it certainly isn't bad. Far from it, in fact. They introduce a lot of interesting concepts/lore in this game that seem to build up to future games. In fact, that would probably be the main reason it isn't as feel-heavy as the previous installments, it's simply not as focused on doing that like the other two games were. That isn't to say it's a boring or soulless experience, either. There are moments akin to those in To the Moon and Finding Paradise, but they're less impactful and less frequent. Instead, focus is shifted to worldbuilding and lore information.

So, with that all said, do I recommend the game? Yes, given you have played To the Moon and Finding Paradise. Whilst it may not be as strong of an entry in the series as the other two, it is still very much an enjoyable experience. The graphics are impressive, the story is good, and the gameplay is streamlined. If you enjoyed the predecessors, than I don't see why you wouldn't enjoy Imposter Factory as well.

Also, the name's sussy, so that's funny

106406453.review:
Another top noch writing from Freebird Games with great pacing between comedic "relief", mystery and "the feels" moments through out this 5-6 hour long journey. Each character feels alive as with the other entiries in the series which contributes to the immersion of the story. This is somewhat linear interactive story than a traditional game, but the incredible story it tells (as do the other entiries in this series, those being To the Moon, Finding Paradise). 

It doesn't require you to play previous games per se, you're still likely get as much kick out of this game as the ones who played the other games, but I'd still suggest you check out the other titles first so this one gets more impactful.

The thing I find the most interesting about this series is that themes get more "mature" with newer entiries. "Mature" in a sense that they show you the lives of different people and give you lessons through them. Each lessons seems impactful in it's own right because they touch on questions that each person ask themselves throughout their life. 

[b][i][u]I[/u][/i][/b]mposter [b][i][u]F[/u][/i][/b]actory shows you what it essentially is about in it's title: "If"s.

Strap your seat belts tight, ladies and gentlemen. Because this shit is heart wrenching as FUCK. But for good reasons.

106383484.review:
LOVE THIS GAME!!!
Played everything in the series. This is my favorite.
You absolutely need to play Finding Paradise before this. Otherwise, a key point in the plot will make far less sense. Playing To The Moon is highly recommended as well. A Bird Story is a good play too, but if you are hesitating on it, you can always play it after these the other 3 main ones. The minisodes are free, so play those too. Sorry if it sounds like I'm inundating you, but this game is so cumulative, and builds on so much, the beauty of it is best appreciated with full context. You'll know what I mean once you play it.
I might have some bias towards this game because of its references to neuroscience (my planned major and interminable interest), but it's narrative is so beautifully woven. Apparently I only spent ~3 hours playing this, but it didn't feel like it (in a good way).
Definitely recommend buying it, regardless of your interests. This series, and to that extent, this game, is 10 years in the making, and it shows. Not that I'm making it sound like this is assuredly that last in the series, but it is still so remarkable for a short game.
Love it, Kan.

106343429.review:
[h1]What I liked: [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Sprint was added
    [*] Cut pointless gameplay elements
    [*] Weirder 
 [/list]
[h1]What I didn’t like: [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Made me feel emotions
    [*] Baited me into being an asshole
[/list]
[h1]My Score: [/h1]
[b]Masterpiece[/b]

[h1]Quick Summary [/h1]
The third game in a trilogy that is simple, short and charming but most importantly it will make you feel and cry. It might not be a video game in the normal sense and you could easily just watch someone play it, you can do that if you feel lonely or cheap, but the experience will be different, fans of Freebird know what they are getting and if you haven’t don’t start with this one as you will not get the full picture, also great job on the misleading marketing as well. 

[h1][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31495025/] My Personal Curator List [/url] [/h1]

[h1]What is a Freebird Game? [/h1]
There are two camps of story games, those that give you choices to affect the story and those that don’t. Imposter Factory is in the latter. The stories always focus on using this device similar to the animus but to let a person go into their mind usually right before death to learn, change or relive their life and make us feel wholesome at times. Usually there is relationship focus and this one is no different. It does have a pretty nice start that I can’t say anything about to spoil. Imposter Factory does further expand and build the universe upon it’s previous 2 games. 

 [h1]Previous Games Encouraged[/h1]
The devs say you don’t need to play the game to enjoy this and that is true for the main character and his story, but there moments usually towards the end that will either feel weird or have no impact and not feel as epic if you don’t play the other 2 in the series, so it’s not required, just strongly encouraged. Just get all 3, they don’t last longer than 5 hours each. 

[h1] It’s All About Character[/h1]
I will mention that if you saw the trailer and expected this wild crazy scif-fi horror/mystery game, it’s a jebait as to not spoil the real story for fans. It focuses more on two characters and their life choices, its ups and downs and carries heavy themes about family, job struggles, working through a relationship and more that will eventually as always make you feel for these characters and maybe even hate them and eventually will at one point break you down. Fans know to expect it and they still throw those emotional punches that hit.

[h1] Less Gameplay =  Better?[/h1]
The gameplay is just a walking simulator and potentially cutscene simulator. Here the complaints from the last game are gone; you can now sprint so it’s a running simulator. Then they made the best discussion to cut the stupid artificial “gameplay” tetris thing that is was used to halt the story. Here you just go to an object tied to the character and collect an orb to unlock the next scene. Usually these orbs are just given after scenes to make sure you see everything and not rush past an important moment or dialogue and no longer halt the pacing and why we play the game the story and characters, mostly written by one guy. It’s almost a style or genre at this point and glad to be supporting this hidden gem and hope you give it a shot and feel the same.

[b]PAID:  $10[/b]
[b]COMPLETED IN: 4 hours[/b]

106271705.review:
The sequel to the hit games To the Moon and Finding Paradise, does it hold up?  I'd say yes.

Unlike the last two games this didn't make me cry but it did have me sitting at my PC for 5 hours straight so it must have done something right.  The real problem I have with this game is it loses its mystery element to quickly and goes onto something else, I wish it had stayed on card and kept with the theme.  That being said its meander doesn't feel undeserved and makes sense at the very least.

The story, despite meandering on themes and tone, still hits all the emotional notes.  And though it didn't have me weeping like the last two titles it still kept me engaged with the story and characters.  It's not afraid to shy away from its themes of existence and what makes a person.  Unlike media like Blade Runner that gives a sort of open idea of what it could be this gives a definitive answer and lets you decide whether its right or wrong in a sort of bitter sweat way.

I want to recommend this.  I really really do.  Its a solid story and it is eager to sock you in the gut with feels over two or three specific characters.  But the humor at points is forced, the murder mystery plot starts out great but is overtaken by an overly long arc of memory exploration, and the ultimate reveal is... not as interesting as one might hope.

If you treat it like an interactive film, its rock solid and a more engaging story than most things I've seen recently even if the reveal killed interest even with the happy ever after scenario.  If you treat it as a video game, it feels sadly lacking.  The ties to the previous games are pleasant and at times a shock.  But I kind of wish it stood on its own which maybe just me being more invested in the murder mystery psuedo-time travel/mirror-worlds introduction than the rest of the game.

105105743.review:
[code]Puedes ver más reseñas como esta en la mentoría [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]Una nueva historia memorable[/h1]

Y ya van tres, he de añadir. El nuevo trabajo de Kan Gao vuelve a ser una auténtica maravilla argumentativa que te masajeará la patata a base de bien mientras, tal vez, sueltas alguna que otra lagrimilla. Sin embargo, hay que hacer algunas apreciaciones importantes.

En esta ocasión, no controlaremos al doctor Watts y a la doctora Rosalene mientras buceamos por las memorias perdidas de un paciente agónico que desea un pasado mejor. Esto al principio puede sonar algo rollo, y lo cierto es que durante la aventura se nota muchísimo la falta del doctor Watts y su humor tan friki.

Sin embargo, el personaje que controlaremos tampoco es manco en frikadas y golpes de humor, aunque en mi opinión no llega al nivel del querido doctor Watts. Pero al menos, tendrá ayuda extra de otros personajes que le ayudarán a hacernos reír bastante. Pero eso mejor que lo descubras personalmente llegado el momento.

Además, Kan Gao ha decidido presentar la historia de una manera muy diferente a lo que pudimos ver en To the Moon o Finding Paradise. Ahora todo será más sorprendente, mucho más oscuro en un primer momento, haciendo que nos encontremos tan perdidos como el propio protagonista de la historia.

Esto dota al título de un aire renovado que le sienta realmente bien, ya que evita caer en la reiteración de planteamientos, aunque tampoco está libre de eso, ya que posteriormente viviremos una aventura conversacional que tira por los mismos derroteros que las otras dos aventuras, presentándonos una historia realmente bonita y que da bastante que pensar sobre la vida y sus vicisitudes.

Es más, Kan Gao se ha venido un poco arriba con esta aventura y ya no solo se limita a tocar temas emocionales, de errores y aciertos, de alegrías y penas, sino que da un paso adelante y se atreve incluso a plantear diferentes teorías de física cuántica bastante actuales. 

Pero no temas, si no conoces el tema del que habla Kan Gao bajo bambalinas tampoco pasa nada porque te quedarás con una historia realmente emocional y de gran calidad, pero si da la casualidad que sí las conoces entonces podrás llegar a comprender la profundidad del tema que trata en esta historia, que es bastante, por cierto.

De todos modos, y para evitar spoilers, solo me voy a referir a la historia principal vagamente. Simplemente para compararla con las anteriores. Después de haber acabado el juego en una sentada, literalmente, la pregunta que me vino a la cabeza fue: ¿Es una historia mejor que las anteriores? La respuesta es no, particularmente me gustaron mucho más las historias de To the Moon y la de Finding Paradise. Además, de lejos. Pero eso no quita para que la historia de este juego sea muy buena igualmente.

Otra pregunta sería: ¿Es el mejor juego creado por Kan Gao hasta la fecha? En mi opinión, sí. Aunque con matices. Como historia principal me han gustado más los otros dos nombrados anteriormente, A Bird Story no lo tengo en cuenta para nada, pero sí es cierto que Impostor Factory es mucho más ambicioso en su argumentativa a nivel global. Muchísimo más, de hecho.

Tal vez el problema sea que la jugabilidad como tal no ha cambiado un ápice desde Finding Paradise. En el juego solo tendremos que hacer clic en pantalla todo el tiempo mientras desplazamos a nuestro personaje por el escenario y se nos va contando la historia de alguien, una historia bonita es cierto, pero nuestra labor será meramente como espectador. Un par de veces o tres podremos elegir una respuesta, pero su impacto es nulo realmente en la aventura.

En To the Moon había pequeños puzles, y a veces había que recorrer bien los escenarios para encontrar las esferas. En Finding Paradise se eliminaron esos mini-puzles, pero el doctor Watts hacía tantas frikadas que te partías de risa. En Impostor Factory las esferas se te caen en las manos, y no hace falta casi ni buscarlas, y eso provoca que la jugabilidad se vuelva terriblemente simple, más aún si cabe. Y la historia de la persona que se nos cuenta no es tan diferente realmente a lo visto en los anteriores juegos, a groso modo claro, pero luego sí es cierto que todo es bastante sorprendente.

Sin embargo, si el tema de la jugabilidad no te importa, si solo quieres disfrutar de una buena historia y punto, aquí vas a encontrar una realmente buena. Eso seguro.

En su aspecto más puramente técnico, el juego no ha cambiado demasiado en el tema gráfico respecto a los anteriores títulos, aunque sí es cierto que me ha parecido todo mejor presentado, con mucha más variedad y muchos detalles de agradecer. Por otra parte, la música es realmente buena, con unos temas muy acertados y de gran calidad.

En definitiva, Impostor Factory ofrece algo memorable en su parte argumentativa, aunque su jugabilidad sea bastante limitada. Puede no llegar a los niveles de las anteriores aventuras, pero eso no es óbice para que no sea realmente magnífica y no muestre una ambición mucho mayor en el fondo de su mensaje. Así que, y una vez más, estamos ante toda una joya que no deberías perderte si vas buscando una historia que realmente te cautive.

104488599.review:
Kan Gao and his team continue to tell simultaneously heartwarming and heart-wrenching stories about what memories mean to us all.

The way we reflect on memories, the way we preserve them and the importance we place on them, are all central to what Freebird Games has become known for.

We are bound by our connections to others and the memories we create with them.

I hope this team continues to make games and I'm already looking forward to their next project.

104482832.review: Great continuation! Looking forward to more!!

104471755.review:
If you've played the other games in the series - To the Moon, A Bird Story, Finding Paradise - then you know what to expect here. That includes an incredible soundtrack that augments exactly what's happening on the screen. Playing this game without music would be missing out on half the game. And if you [i]haven't[/i] played those other games then stop reading this and start playing To the Moon immediately!

There's not quite as much experimentation with the mechanics as last time, which I consider an improvement, but the story, and really the narrative structure are somewhat more experimental here than before. Repetition is a very purposeful motif, used effectively.

Impostor Factory asks big, bold questions. What should your priorities be? Is it ok to be a little selfish? And ultimately, how does one live a good, meaningful life?

The craziest thing here is that the game actually manages to answer those questions, and answer them well, while still leaving some wiggle room for interpretation.

And the real strength is that there's also room for you, for injecting yourself into the characters and thinking about how you would react in their situation. Once again, just like with To the Moon, this game generated countless discussions for me in real life, because the scenarios it brought to my mind were worth talking to other people about. More than that: I [i]had[/i] to talk through those ideas.

Parents, be warned, you will be hit far harder here than anyone who has never had kids.

I get why this game took so long now. It's not that the graphics or the engine are doing spectacularly complicated things. It's that the experience had to be finely crafted so that you arrive at the right place in the emotional arc for what was going to happen next. And it works marvelously.

I still think To the Moon is the better game. Maybe just because I played it first. But this came closer than anything else has to achieving that same journey.

It's a masterpiece of story telling.

104424159.review:
An average game usually tends to have some aspects expanded to a certain level. It'll have combat system, it'll have story, soundtrack, character development, options to choose from, and so on... If you play it and the story sucks, it doesn't neccesarily mean that it's bad. You still may have fun exploring the map and beating the s h i t out of enemies.

However, [i]Impostor Factory[/i] is very limited in this sense. The gameplay is pretty much only about controlling the character and looking at objects. There isn't much else to do. But: is it good? Hell yeah it's good.

The game is based mainly on the plot. If the story doesn't deliver because it feels uninspired or rushed, you'll be disappointed. But, the story is immersive and incredibly thought-provoking. This 4th installment in the series ([i]A Bird Story[/i] included) has been outlined by Kan Gao, the writer, 10 years ago or more. He does his job very well and that's why I don't really worry about the quality of [i]Freebird Games's[/i] games before they release. There's no place for changing major aspects of the project a year before the premiere, which is very common in the AAA titles production. Good planning leads to good product.

The story is perfectly supported with, yet again, magnificent soundtrack. Lots of different songs, adjusted brilliantly to the setting and momentum.

My favourite game of all-time is [i]Finding Paradise[/i], so a previous game in the series, and I'm not going to lie, [i]Impostor Factory[/i] is as good. But if I were to pick one, I'd choose the former as it was a significantly longer game.

It's good, but not as good as the other two (which you need to have played first, btw). It lacks the emotional through-line that the others had, and instead focuses more on concluding the series and providing context. And for this reason it's definitely the weakest of the three.
It's also shorter than the other two (just over 3 hours); longer than Bird Story (just over 1 hour), but not as long as To The Moon (5 hours) or Finding Paradise (5.5 hours).
I would also describe it more akin to BS, insofar as whilst it's a continuation of the main story, it also tells it in a side-story kind of way. For example, the two main characters from TTM and FP barely feature at all [spoiler](at least, not in the way we recognise them)[/spoiler], and the story is more told to you, similar to what was done in BS.

Did I like the game? Yes.
Is it still a good story? Yes.
Is the music still outstanding? Yes.
Did I get emotionally invested in pixels again and cry just like the others? Yes.
Would I recommend you play it? Yes, just be aware that, IMO, it plays more like BS and less like TTM and FP, and doesn't carry the same emotional impact that they did.

104245768.review:
I guess within the circle of people who play these games, one of the main questions is, "How hard did this one hit you?"

Well this one just happened to melt me into a giant sobbing baby for about 15 minutes, and I'm a 37 year old man.

And I think that's the thing about these games - they're all contemplations on life and death, and how they resonate with you will depend on what your own life has been like, and where you are in your own timeline when you play the game.

Impostor Factory, much like the other games, encourages you to think about your own choices and your own regret. And the older you get, the more overwhelming the idea of branching possibilities becomes. What life could you have created for yourself? What children could you have brought into the world? Who could you have made happier? Are there times where you prioritized your own needs when others around you needed you more? I think most people probably don't spend much time contemplating these things, but this game may certainly move you to do so.

Towards the end of the game, a mysterious character remarks, "To me, time is just a place." It comforts me to think about time in this way. The fear of death is largely due to time's linearity, the idea that after death is oblivion, and your life no longer exists. Impostor Factory reminds us that we always exist, that our piece of time is there forever, and even if we may not be able to access it, it's still something we leave behind. It's both calming and empowering - make the best choices you can in life, people, because those choices are infinite.

Anyway, the rice is perfect, cat protec, boxing gloves. Memes lol

103780744.review:
Impostor Factory is the third main entry in the To the Moon series, and honestly, I don't even know where to begin with the review, so as not to spoil anything. As with the previous games, I can start by saying that the people at FreeBird Games managed to craft a beautiful story one more time.

This time, however, things are slightly different. While the previous games followed the (mis)adventures of Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene as they do their jobs for Sigmund Corp, in this one you'll play as Quincy, a regular guy who one day gets invited to a party in a fancy mansion. I mean, you could get that from the game's description, but honestly I feel that's all I can say without spoiling the story. Just let me add that it still has that emotional beauty found in To the Moon and Finding Paradise, by the end, it'll make you cry.

The writing, as always, is top-notch. It's a very touching, emotional story, and they also manage to write in some sillyness to lighten up the mood, which, in my opinion, is necessary for the themes these games touch, so as not to make the story too depressing.

As for gameplay, well, it's what you'd expect from a game in this franchise; it plays like a relatively simple and straightforward RPG. After all, these games are about the story more than anything else, and the gameplay remains simple enough so as not to hinder the main part of the game. A similar thing could be said about the art style, it's a somewhat simple style reminiscent of old JRPGs, but it's still full of charm. And, as always, the game's got a great soundtrack.

For some final words, I can say I really, really recommend this game, especially if you're already a fan of the series. Now I want to see what the people at FreeBird do next.

103590745.review:
So, again the Steam review issue, that it's binary yes/no.
This is not a bad game. Or, well, experience.
But it is a boring one. And almost not a game.

This comes from a fan of the series, a seriously artsy fartsy guy who cried his fair share through the emotional tricks and triggers - so it's not a case of some action Jackson just wanting more flash & bang.

But what I would like, is more game.

If at times, the earlier installments might have suffered from too much retro-gaming nostalgia, inserting unnecessary gaming elements that got in the way of the story, this installment goes the opposite way, foregoing almost all gaming to tell a linear on-the-rails slice-of-life story.

And it gets boring. At its most egregious it is in act 2, where it's pretty much a slideshow, where you just press right to activate the next cutscene, for what? Almost an hour? I do not feel invested. I do not feel a part of it. I do not feel that I can effect a change, or even move the story forward.

I am simply an observer. If this'd be a film, or a book, it'd be fine. The expectations would be different. But going through an "interactive experience" without your actions ever really interfacing with the experience is a waste of the medium. Repeatedly rooms lacked interactivity. Everything was super linear and basic. 

Even the visuals became more barren/rudimentary as the game progressed, and evoked a feeling of a project that had run out of steam/funding/time two-thirds through. Details like pathways between cutscenes starting out misty and handcrafted, to becoming just straight dragged gradient brushes.

The writing was hyper-expository, everything was constantly spelled out, nothing left to be figured out. And some of the topics, sadly, felt like "oh I heard this cool thing in philosophy 101".

The earlier installments might not have been literary masterpieces, but they made me feel. This one, made me feel bored.

103520805.review:
Get your tissues ready, because this one is a doozy! What starts out as a murder mystery quickly morphs into something else entirely that will have you guessing what the fuck is going on from beginning to end. You laugh, you will be delighted and you will cry. 

This entry hit me the hardest out of all the entries in the To The Moon series. However, I also think Imposter Factory is the weakest entry in the series by far in terms of characters, narrative and game design. The cast this time around just isn't memorable in the same way as the previous ones were. They are great in the moment, but you won't remember them like Johnny and River. Gone are all of the little quirks and nooks you could find when exploring. They have been replaced by some absolutely gorgeous pixel art and linear level design, which is pretty, but lacks the depth previous entries in the series had. Neil and Eva are largely relegated to a cameo at the end, which was super disappointing, as I loved their banter, Neil's crazy random antics, and their sub plot in the previous games. The narrative here does address their sub plot from the previous games, but it's disappointing that it does so without them. I felt their appearance also destroyed the closure the ending brought. I really hope this isn't the last entry in this series like they said it would be back when they were developing it. As there is clearly much more story to tell. You also NEED to play through the previous entries in the series before playing this one. If you don't you will be lost when it comes to the main narrative, as it heavily ties back into the previous games. 

Despite these shortcomings, Impostor Factory is still one hell of a ride and is worth picking up if you're a fan of the To The Moon series. Just don't expect anything on the same level as the previous entries.

102967776.review:
I wish I could leave a neutral review, though on net I'll say it's positive. Impostor Factory is easily the weakest entry in the To The Moon series, and this episode is not a stand alone: I don't believe I would have understood what was going on if I didn't know the lore. But if you do care about the lore, you must play this one.

I made it through the entire game without crying and that's a bit of a disappointment for a Freebird Game. There are certainly sad things in the game, but nothing actually raised to the level of sobbing that the previous games induced.
The graphics and engine are better than the previous games, and that's appreciated. Gameplay wise, there's a lot of just moving right through a corridor, with no other interactivity, which is a regression: there's very little exploration of the scenes. The music is lovely as always, but there's no stand out theme. There was no "For River" or "Faye's Theme" that were immediately unforgettable.

There is no way to talk about the story and why it's interesting without total spoilers, so spoilers ahead:

---

In the end, everything takes place in one of SigmundCorp's machines. Neil Watts' mother, Lynri, was involved in building some of the scanning technology used across the series and left Neil a copy of her emgrams. Neil is now apparently experimenting on his mother's brain scans on his own time, and that scan is apparently conscious. Even though Neil appears to be doing this to give his mother a posthumous equivalent of what he and Eva have given dying patients in previous games, there's questions about whether Lynri consented to any of this and thus Neil might be committing a mindcrime on a copy of his mother.

There's also the question of what happens to two conscious minds at the end of the game. If they're terminated, that should be read as Neil committing murder, as they're running on Neil's hardware instead of on a decaying human body. But if they're left alive...then the To The Moon universe has reached a civilizational victory condition: mind uploading plus out-of-body simulation.

If you still needed a meat brain to run a human mind, SigmundCorp's services in To The Moon and Finding Paradise make sense. But if you don't, taking a scan right before death is a straightforward path to digital immortality...and it questions what SigmundCorp is even doing in the first two games. Lynri's scan is done before the events of the first two games, so brain scanning in enough detail could have been done for River or for Colin. Faye shows up on Neil's terminal so maybe they did.

But if so, why isn't this mentioned in universe? Why does SigmundCorp have the business model that it does? "We will scan your brain on your deathbed since the invention of running uploaded scans is imminent" would be a much easier sell than "We will modify your memories at the end of your life."

102926252.review:
Steam really should have a sideways thumb option. Anyhow.

To The Moon was a great game. Finding Paradise was a great game. Impostor Factory is NOT a great game. In particular:

The claim that Impostor Factory contains "A cozy mix between adventure game elements and classic RPG aesthetics" is FALSE. Impostor Factory does not contain adventure game elements. Previous titles at least included very small minigames to keep the player engaged; they also contained item descriptions which encouraged players to interact and engage with their environment. Impostor Factory, in contrast, is far more passive, especially in its second act. For large parts of the game, gameplay consists of walking along constrained corridors, talking to the only NPC available to interact with to obtain story dialogue, then repeating. That is not "adventure".

The first and third acts are what redeem the game. These sections afford a small amount of player freedom, and reward the player's efforts to talk to different NPCs. The dialogue in these sections is frequently witty and charming, and was the highlight of the game for me. Two of the sidekicks, in particular, were excellent, showing off the calibre of writing that the studio is capable of.

Aside from that, fans of the series may find themselves being invested in the lore contained in Impostor Factory.

Those who haven't played To The Moon or Finding Paradise should 100% play those titles instead. Do not start with Impostor Factory. The relative weaknesses in Impostor Factory may deter new players from investigating the series further. Experienced fans of the series will find Impostor Factory worth it in the end, but should go in with lowered expectations. It's not a great game. It's not a bad game. It's... okay.

102904179.review:
Giving this a THUMBS DOWN for mainly one reason: in terms of what I look for in the "visual novel" genre, this game failed in the ways that count the most.
Although, yes, this story is probably the weakest in the "To the Moon" series, it's still maybe my favorite since it primarily concerns [spoiler] one of the main characters and the origins of the technology used by Sigmund Corp. I think this marks a potential turning point in the possibilities of future installments, in ways I'd absolutely look forward to.[/spoiler]

However, the game is a huge letdown in terms of how the story unfolds. The whole thing is linear to an alarmingly literal sense, in that often, the only direction you can move your character is forward, and the game allows for little interactions outside of the plot-specific NPCs to talk to or objects to click on. The previous installments of the franchise have vast environments for you to explore, so even when the game only progresses with certain actions you still feel totally immersed in the story. In Impostor Factory, however, it felt more like I'm side scrolling through panels of a comic book.

And I think that's the biggest disappointment here: I'd rather have paid for a full-length graphic novel version of this chapter of "To the Moon" than for the game itself. Had this been something I could read instead of play, I'd have loved the beautiful story within the pages. But playing this lessened its impact because I was constantly frustrated by the lack of engagement. Visual novels as a medium are so great to me because they allow for a lot more flexibility and creativity for the creators, to huge benefits on behalf of the "reader," but this was little more than moving from point A to point B as the story is told around the reader. I dislike that very much.

TL;DR 9/10 for story, 4/10 for gameplay

102662882.review:
Warning: If you hate a sappy self indulgent essay, SKIP. I mean it lol. 

This is my personal review of this game:

For me, this game really hit me where it really hurts.

For context, my mom died of cancer recently. I've been just so numb to it a lot of time. But this game, this game reminded me of why it really hurt. It reminded me that I'll never mom grow old with dad, despite fighting for so long, despite all the sacrifices. That feeling where she'll never be able to take care of her grandkids, just as she always wanted. She was the smartest, bravest, most generous soul I have ever known in my life. I always thought that she could've been so much more than just a housewife taking care of stupid old me and my sisters. She could've been an amazing lawyer, like she once wanted. I talked to her about it, and guess what she said. She said I, and my sisters, were her pride and joy, that there's nothing more in this world that makes her happy than us.

Life had not been kind to my mom. She was dealt the worst cards she could handle, even before cancer, and yet someone like her could be so amazing. That's why I wish I was better. I wish I could've paid her back. I wish I could make her happier and prouder. 

I might not get the technical details of what Neil did, but I definitely know why he did it. What his mom did was amazing. A self-sacrificing, unconditional act of love that only a mother could make. I KNOW he wanted to pay her back, even if we all know that's impossible.  

Neil, you did good buddy. And go confess to Eva already you tsundere dumbass!

And Kan Gao, thank you. Thank you for reminding me that we should be better. We might not be the person we want to be in the future, but at least we can choose to be a little bit better one day at a time.

Ma, I miss you so hard, I love you so much, and I'll be better like you always wanted me to be.

102522781.review:
If you’re a gamer who’s had their eye ever on the RPGMaker engine, it’s fair to assume you know who Freebird Games is.  Proverbially smashing into the indie scene 10 years ago with their detailed masterpiece, To The Moon, Freebird has since added a sequel in 2017 and brings a continuation and possible end to the Sigmund Corp franchise with Impostor Factory.  I’ll forewarn, this game is weird, and somewhat hard to wrap your head around at times, but bear with me: it’s worth it.

On a rainy day in front of a disheveled yet grandiose terrace, Quincy attends a party where the status quo is quite a few tax brackets higher than himself.  While the outside is damp and disarranged, the inside of the mansion is as pristine as the proclaimed germaphobe tenants can make it.  In this sprawling two story abode: scientists, investors, big wigs, and some in between find themselves attending to see a mechanical miracle that could change the world in ways never seen before.  Before Quincy and company can see what’s in store for them, Quincy stumbles upon the freshly murdered bodies of the mansion’s owners.  Unraveling at the seams, Quincy runs to the bathroom to avoid suspicion and explanation.  After washing the blood from his hands when checking the bodies, he returns to a similar scene not a few minutes earlier.  None of the guests were the wiser of what happened because the mansion’s residents are still alive and well.  What lays ahead for Quincy is what can be best described as Clue mixed with Groundhog Day.

But hold on friends, this is only the first part of the game.  Impostor Factory builds itself into its own name as the genre of this title changes almost by the hour, going from a darkly comedic whodunit into something creator Kan Gao is more known for: heart-string tugging love stories.  Genre changes this abrupt should have to go through some bumpiness, but the love and care taken into the two character’s backstory is so engulfing, engaging, and provoking that you almost forget this game was making you laugh with its ridiculousness.  Within minutes you’re now in Impostor Factory’s grip with how somber and captivating the history between these two are and time feels like it stops with how hard it pulls you in.

And it builds tremendously upon its middle act.  Impostor Factory serenades the player with a wave of simple yet beautiful piano scores throughout.  Engaging enough to liven a scene yet subdued enough to appreciate the details of the flashbacks: it’s these tender moments that get enunciated that shine the brightest and hit the hardest.  Dealing with the ups and downs, slips and falls, the highest highs and lowest lows, and the simplistic in-betweens that most couples cherish the most.  The amount of emotional weight of the two characters pressed on the player is astonishing given the minimal amount of time used and a true testament to the emotional genius Gao is at his craft.

When that emotional weight carries into Impostor Factory’s third act, the strands of a lifelong journey intertwined by a choice encounter start to tie together with familiar characters and the twists and turns that are revealed provide a beautifully poignant end to the absolute roller coaster of a story.  The choices and paths led after all the mysteries are laid out tear deep and all I could was just admire the quintessential direction of Quincy’s story until the credits rolled and I could exhale after what felt like an eternity of holding my breath for them.

Emotionally, I’m exhausted.  But mentally, I’m so happy I spent the time diving head first into Impostor Factory.  Kan Gao shows once again the supreme talent and direction he’s used over the past decade to tell a funny, imaginative, and emotionally crushing tale of living life to the fullest no matter the obstacles thrown in front of you.  Now if you’ll excuse me, I’m going to put back on the OST and try not to cry.

...I’m gonna cry a lot.

[quote][h1]Follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33247611/]A Review Is Worth 1,000 Words[/url] for more Steam Reviews.[/h1][/quote]

Imposter Factory is possibly(?) the final entry for the "To The Moon" series. IF (Imposter factory) clarified what the whole series is all about. 

I'm gonna say it outright, I think this entry was the weakest of all the games but that doesn't mean it is bad. This game is still good for its price and unique experience as a standalone, but compared to previous entries it's weak. I'm gonna list why below:

1) All previous entries has added new, unique and quirky gameplay elements as an ice breaker or a moment of relief from the feels, be it a puzzle or a parody of old JRPGs. This game has NONE OF THAT

2) All the previous entries had an unexpected twist which serves as a trigger to start crying while you get hit by the FEELS truck. While IF also has a twist, it felt predictable and weak and it Failed to break my "Guard" against the "Feels"

The Disappointment is I guess more for the fans the previously played everything since the start. They chose the safe route to wrap up everything nicely but that's what made this entry weak. There was no HOLY SHIT, or WHOAH reveal at the end. 

It's been almost 10 years since the first entry, To The Moon, was released. And while I was disappointed with how they ended the series, I hope Freebird Games continue its great storytelling to something new. 

Regardless of the downsides I said above, if you are new to the series or starting with this game, this is still a 7/10 good game.

102414596.review:
As a fan of Freebird Game's other entries, I have to say I'm disappointed.

The FAQ section says you can play Impostor Factory without playing the first two. This is straight up wrong. If you don't know the characters from the other games, the ending will be meaningless and confusing.

I've played the first two games and enjoyed them very much, but it's been four years since the last installment.  My entire experience during the end was struggling to remember who everyone was and how they we're connected to everything else. If you don't know the characters from the other games, there will be almost no payoff to the story whatsoever. There isn't much payoff for the characters you come to know in this game regardless.

The opening, the screenshots, and the game description of a "bonkers time-loop tragicomedy" really hammer home the idea that this one's going to be something different. It's not. After a compelling Act 1 setup, Act 2 gives way for a storytelling experience much more akin to the first two games, albeit significantly blander and feeling disconnected from the first act. The final act offers lame explanations for the intrigue that was set up at the beginning and does little more than furthering of the stories outside of it's own neglected narrative.

If you're familiar with the other games, and you wash the expectations Act 1 sets up, you can probably have a good time. Other than that, I can't recommend it.

102407472.review:
tl;dr: decent game but all story, practically no gameplay; about 4 hours to beat; some feels to be had if you care to; surprisingly bloody compared with the previous games; a little too much pseudo-technical gibberish to justify the plot towards the end; features several meme-based lines in case you're allergic to those; once again ends on sequel bait.

Another decent interactive story from the To the Moon series. It's a little under four hours (my playtime is at 4.2 hours, which includes the game sitting idle a couple of times while I was busy AFK), nothing all that different from the previous games: it's still only a little more involved gameplay-wise than Dear Esther: you just walk from one scene to another, occasionally clicking to talk to someone, or to inspect or use an object. The game's strength lies more in the feels department, though it didn't hit as strongly as the first game. Impostor Factory also featured considerably more blood than I'd expected from the series.

If you pardon me for being vague in order to reduce spoilers, I found that making the story partly about the mechanics or rules of the simulation towards the end killed both my interest in the intrigue and my emotional investment in the characters. Since I'm already complaining about the story, I'll also include several lines being meme-based. Memes in creative writing (or any medium other than websites for funny pictures) tend to stand out as creative low-hanging fruit and date the work that uses them.

102164092.review:
Hoooooo boyyyy
This game definitely didn't go into the direction I anticipated it to. Having played To The Moon and Finding Paradise, I knew this game would be another gem, and I waited for it with baited breath. Now I can definitively say that the wait was absolutely worth it. With a masterful soundtrack to accompany the intricately woven story--all of which you follow through Quincy's eyes--this game is (supposedly) a near-perfect addition to a trilogy that I personally believe to be absolutely amazing. This is sequels done right, and I very much look forward to seeing more from Freebird Games in the future.
A sentimental story with plenty of well-done comedy sprinkled inbetween, this is definitely one for your recommended if you're interested in a few hours of simply guiding your character through his story. Gameplay-wise, it might have been a bit less of a game and a bit more of a visual novel, but for me that was a strength rather than a weakness: The pace was set well enough to simply allow you to progress through the story without it feeling rushed nor getting stuck and losing the thread of the story while playing.

If you haven't yet, definitely play To The Moon and Finding Paradise before this game, as it does tie in pretty strongly into those two games. Besides, you won't regret the money spent on this trilogy.

102136075.review:
This game was an absolute disappointment.

I really love To the Moon, it is one of my favorite games of all time, and one of the few games that made me actually cry. Finding Paradise I thought wasn't as strong as To the Moon, but it is still a solid game with a great story. When I found out they were making a sequel/another entry in the series, I was really pumped, and I anticipated for the day it would come out.

Then the game came out. 

It starts off really well actually. Starting off in what appears to be a generic mansion party of sorts, only to spiral into some kind of weird reality twisting nightmare. (This part I am not sure is a spoiler but I'll spoiler it anyway) [spoiler] We even see a a really sad story, on how we got into the situation and one of the characters behind the whole thing. [/spoiler] It's really nice actually and it's a high point in the game. Later on the game has a twist that I thought was kinda nice, but everything after that starts to trip over its own feet and go downhill.

This next part is a big spoiler view at your own risk. [spoiler] The entire game takes place within the memory altering machine that previous characters, Neil and Eva use throughout the series. Essentially Quincy is a memory entity and Lynri (the character responsible for the memory device and the predicament you are in) is trying to work some bugs out only for the thing the glitch out and spawn Faye from Finding Paradise. Why is Faye in this? I don't know? I always thought she was a figment of Collin's imagination but now she is vital part of the machine. She later goes on to explain that there exist many realities within the machine, and the reality where the previous characters from the last game exist in another reality raising the question if any of the previous games were even real within the To the Moon universe. Then for some reason Faye gathers all the alternate versions of Quincy and Lynri to destroy the imperfect world, and create a perfect world for Quincy and Lynri. We never find out what reality actually happened as Faye says that the previous realities where just one of the many that we could implant. That is until you see the post-credit scene, where we see a scene with Neil in the machine. But even then, I had to look up what exactly even happened, and even now that I know what reality is real, the story still doesn't make sense. I feel like there are a lot plot holes. Like how is Neil viewing his dead mother's memories when she is already dead!? Did he get them from his father or something? [/spoiler]  

Essentially the game pulls off a ton of deus ex machina alternate universe BS that really toyed with me and my understanding of everything I have come to know from the series. It's a decent story but not

The gameplay (and this is gonna sound stupid but follow me on this ok) feels incredibly lackluster compared to the previous entries. I know the last two games weren't all complex with what they were but here is the thing. This game was a linear walking simulator compared to the rest of the game. I know you don't do much in the previous games either, but you still had to explore your small environment and uncover the pieces to advance to the next part of the story. But here you are literally on a one way path. You don't explore, you just walk and get a piece of the puzzle to break the barrier to advance. Idk how but this is like a downgraded version of the previous games gameplay. They're aren't even any puzzles to do before you advance. I got nothing against games that prioritize story over gameplay, but the story just isn't good.

I did like a lot of the funny moments in the game, but they are not enough to salvage it. Sorry ricebot and long kitty.

I guess some other merits I can list off is that the Art is really nice, the music is great, and the pixel animation is really good in this one.

When I first beat To the Moon and Finding Paradise I felt good. Like I experienced a genuine emotional ride. And I left with a bittersweet feeling (the games made me sad ok, good would be a weird way to describe an experience of an emotional game). This game, I literally just sat at my computer as the credits rolled and was just like: "What the heck was that?" I didn't feel anything, just confusion and emptiness.

Freebird Games are full of talented people and they make incredible games with some of the best story and music. I really hope this entire review doesn't come across as an attack on the team and their work. I love To the Moon, and I even enjoyed Finding Paradise. I didn't have any strong expectations for this game, hell I didn't even know what to expect.

But this game feels really weak compared to its predecessors. It's Story had good build up but bad pay off, and it somehow managed to make the gameplay very lackluster somehow (I know that last part sounded weird but that's how I can describe it).

I am sorry, but I don't think Imposter Factory is worth it. I can't recommend it.

I am not angry, just disappointed.

Despite all that, I still recommend playing [i]Impostor Factory[/i] if you liked the previous games. For context. [u]Only[/u] for context.

102103373.review:
So this game has overwhelmingly positive reviews which means it clearly was enjoyed and something that resonated with a lot of people. However it didn't resonate with me. I'll explain why--but do keep in mind how positive the other reviews are when making a decision on buying this.

On with the show. Impostor Factory is the third game of this series, proceeded by Finding Paradise and To the Moon. These games tend to tell emotionally involved stories with puzzles to figure out about how to progress.

Unfortunately, I found that Impostor Factory retreads the same ideas present in To the Moon and Finding Paradise without meaningfully pushing the overarching narrative of the series forward or evolving the writing in a meaningful way. The first two games are tearjerkers, but it doesn't feel like the developers have progressed since To the Moon released in 2011, which quickly gives the game a dated feel. 

The gameplay here is actually simpler than the first two, with the puzzle elements removed entirely from progression. You'll walk and talk, and that's about it. I think some people may enjoy not needing to figure out puzzles to continue the plot, but for me I felt like it was a regression from the previous two entries and an unfortunate omission.

With that said, the writing here IS good, but I was disappointed that the game throws away its most interesting ideas early on to retread the same tropes & half-opened mystery box styled writing that featured heavily in To the Moon and Finding Paradise. This made it much more difficult for me to invest in the game because while Freebird Games does tell good stories, they seem to have gotten stuck telling the same story over and over and over again. Instead of the revelations coming as a shock, I rolled my eyes as the game proceeded down the same patterns as its predecessors without growth.

Those of you looking for some closure on this decade-long series might also leave frustrated. While this game really does need the first two in the series to be played and understood, I don't think this game does much to meaningfully push the narrative forward for those of us who have been following for a decade now. This is a shame because--again, the writing is good! But it feels like every game Freebird Games releases is another take at Act 1 of a greater story. They're all great Act 1s, but after a decade I'd like an Act 2.

And that's where I'm at. This sequel disappointed me, but at least part of that is on me for wanting it to be more of a continuation than it is. I'd still like to see that next game that progresses the plot, but if the next game Freebird releases is another side story? I'll probably skip it.

101910364.review:
[u]This review was written by a crying Yuukazami who experienced something that really hits the feels ;-;[/u]

I continue to be impressed by the surreal comedy that Freebird brings me, the amazing stories that really does make me feel emotional and in the end, I feel like this really did inspire me to become a writer again. I don't know why, but... I just have to start writing! Well, obviously, this review is only the start of it. It made me want to get back into writing my diary book again! The same one I neglected for a few months. Talk about being consistent.

But never mind all that talk of me wanting to write stuff again, lets get on with talking about the game. It's excellent. Seriously, it is. If you really want to get into a story that you can deeply immerse yourself in roughly 4-5 hours, please, give it a try. But, do play the previous games, like [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/206440/To_the_Moon/]To The Moon[/url] or [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/337340/Finding_Paradise/]Finding Paradise[/url], along with it's in-betweens. Some would say it's not really necessary to play the games that are between To The Moon and Impostor Factory, but, really, give those a try too. Seriously, the minisodes are free downloadable content, and who doesn't like free stuff?

 If you want my suggestion, don't play it all in one go, perhaps it's best to have a day off or two when playing the entirety of the series.

But, anyway, the developers had left a handy little list of key features here in the description that I'll go through.
[list]
[*] A story that will make you curse at the screen (Close enough)

[*] A cozy mix between adventure game elements and classic RPG aesthetics (I think there's something more in it than just that small mix)

[*] Dialogues that read so wrong but feel so right (I can't believe I read the entirety of ACT 1 out loud. The things that I've said...)

[*] An espresso execution with zero filler and no time drains (You can definitely square that one, because it's there! Well done!!)

[*] long cat (Is this the first time we see a long cat in a game? Someone please verify below!)
[/list]

But yeah. Awesome game, go try it.
10/10

101803095.review:
I have to say I recommend the game. However, it is the weakest installment of the series so far.

The graphics certainly got a bit more polish and flair this time around and the visual presentation is a big success. It looks great, it's not by a mile, but if you've played To The Moon recently, it's noticeably better. From the spritework, to the map designs and some of the effects, most notably the now animated barriers, everything seems to have received an extra layer of love.

The gameplay and pacing are very different. This one is even less of a game than the other two. Granted, if you've played the other two, you know what you're getting into, but now there's just less of it as a result. This means a little less padding by having you search every nook and cranny but it does feel more straight to the point and they did pack in a lot of info back there. I wish our playable character kept commenting a bit more, during the second act, as he tends to fall silent for pretty long stretches of time where it seems like he could've been a little more fleshed out. We're pretty far from the previous games' pair of protagonists sharing theories and opinions at the end of basically every minor scene. However the choice of having stills on the way that you don't interact with but still properly convey story beats and emotions is not only a good choice, but also well executed.

The music is a bit of a let down. It hurts to say, because it's objectively fine, but you can't escape comparison with the past titles. The main recurring theme doesn't stand tall on its own and isn't nearly as memorable as the ones from TTM and FP. The range of music is also not as great, especially compared to FP which had an excellent range of moods within its soundtrack. The absence of diegetic music is also a first, there isn't a compelling reason why the main character doesn't play an instrument to fill that role. It would've rounded the character and might've helped the soundtrack feel a little more alive. It used to be such a prominent feature of the other games that it's disappointing to get a soundtrack that very much feels like background music this time around.

-Spoilers Ahead-

The story was not bad. The initial fake out of a murder mystery felt unnecessary in retrospect but I have to admit some of what they did was just unnerving enough to make me wonder what an actual horror game made by that team could look like, so as a framing device and source of conflict, that was weak, but the execution was ok. The main character's life story was fairly predictable, both the simulated one and the actual one we learn about later on were fairly standard affairs and not all that difficult to see coming from a mile away. They didn't keep me guessing like TTM or FP did, it was a very conventional narrative that doesn't really feel unexplored anymore in medias. In fact, I'm surprised that the game never addressed how much travelling the world and mending the rift in the relationship as a result was a Plan B. Nobody commented on the fact that without a deadly accident and failure of her current project, their couple might not have lasted. Quincy had literally just started to speak up about it and he basically had his needs met by pure random "luck", but never confronted the possibility that he would've absolutely kept being miserable or lost her entirely if the presentation worked out. 

The twist meta-story left a lot to be desired. It's interesting that they went that way and the new themes explored are fun for a twist, but it does leave us with a taste that most of what we saw was more or less meaningless. In previous games, you could at least get the feeling that all of this was done for the benefit of an individual, but in this one, the only real actor here is Neil. Faye is there for the ride and because she has a job to do, but she didn't seem to be especially touched by these events. I get that Neil working to create a perfect ending is, in some way, personal growth and beneficial for his character. At least it would be, if he wasn't shown to have a cynical view toward what he ended up creating. Plus, he has to be painfully aware that making a simulation comfortable isn't the same as an actual person. Whether that actually constitute a meaningful event remains to be seen in future titles. It didn't help that if you consider the murder mystery as the red herring that it is, then this twist is more or less the only actual surprise the game has for you, and it's basically telling that none of it is real, including the participants. I was honestly hoping for more, but after seeing the prominent tentacles and end of the world narrative the trailer promised, I guess I shouldn't be too mad they didn't play that one straight. On its own, it's a pretty poor twist, but there ARE a few ways the next game could retroactively make this one more relevant. For example, if they decide that Eva ends up finding out everything and has to confront the idea that she works with someone who is sick, might have feelings for her (or feel she's part of his perfect ending) and has to reconcile with the idea she's working with someone who uses the technology on himself to create perfect ending for virtual recreations of his loved ones as a coping mechanism, personal quest or just as a hobby. The tease of the possibility of a next game is the main thing that doesn't make this story a total letdown.

-End of Spoilers-

In the end, I recommend this games to fans of the series. It is absolutely not a good idea to try and enjoy this game as a standalone. It only works with the context of the previous titles and might actually work better if more titles are yet to come. It is not the highest note to end the series on, so hopefully it's not the end. However, it is still objectively a good game and the only reason I'm being harsh with it is that I feel that series, and even this specific installment, deserve the scrutiny and the discussion. I still think it deserves to be experienced by those who would appreciate it even if I feel that team gave us more solid and memorable experiences in the past.
