101605903.review:
An extremely fine game.

Although none of the later games in this series have landed with quite the same sob-inducing impact as To The Moon, Impostor Factory follows in same vein in that:
[list]
    [*]It is extraordinarily well made.  Graphics, sound, etc. achieve exactly what the makers intend, and that bar is high.
    [*]It demonstrates that the author is really doing deep thinking about life, death, love, and our responsibilities in our relationships and toward humanity.  And that he really wants to share that with the viewers and have us think about it also.
    [*]It is just plain great storytelling.  Simple as that.
[/list]

That being said, Impostor Factory has significant differences from To The Moon and Finding Paradise.  First thing, it's not a sequel.  It's (except for some end-game material and a very important after-credits sequence) essentially a prequel to the other games, walking you through the personal stories around how the memory-interface technology in this world was originally developed, and why. It continues to build on the broader implications of the memory technology for human life and society, implications that the characters themselves incompletely grasp.

It also has, somehow, even fewer game-y elements than the prior main games.  Exploration is only a tool here to increase your investiture and to optimize story pacing, nothing else.  It's also a bit shorter than the other main games, though nowhere near as short as the interlude games.  Finally, this is clearly not an entry point.  Anyone playing this series should go in release order (skipping the interlude short-games if they like).

I'm not going to spoil any more than that.  Playing this is a wonderful experience.  Most people will love it.

The story is engaging and interesting, and the soundtrack accompanies it all really well. This game drops some of the mini-games present in the previous entries and made it clearer what was necessary to progress, something that I think was a terrific decision, as it removed potential points of frustration or confusion, and really leaned into the story telling aspect which is where it shines the most. There are still places to explore and extra interactables to find, giving depth to the scenes. I highly recommend playing through this game if you're looking to experience an interesting story, and if at all possible I recommend playing through it all in one sitting or with minimal breaks, to really immerse yourself in its world.

This was another excellent story in the series.

In this respect, though, it's probably the weakest entry in the series, as I felt it didn't have quite the same emotional impact as the previous entries. What sets this apart from the other games is the stronger mystery element, and the furthering of the wider story in the series. This kept the story very compelling, and is the reason it continued to pull me through. The latter part of the game is particularly good, as the revelations are thought-provoking, while also supplying a satisfying conclusion.

Overall, it's probably not as strong as To The Moon or Finding Paradise, but is still a very good game in its own right. Given how the furthering of the wider series story is one of the key elements, this probably isn't a good place to start if you haven't played To The Moon or Finding Paradise yet (which you should definitely play anyway). If you have, though, Impostor Factory is a great experience.

101378957.review:
If you can get it for $3 or less, and don't mind it being almost entirely irrelevant to the overarching plot we've experienced thus far, go for it. It saddens me to say this, because there are some very touching moments, and the sprite artwork and music are both absolutely on point. It's just lacking in a few important ways, and has a twist ending that renders the entire thing pointless. I have this feeling like they attempted to go deep and philosophical, but missed the mark horribly.

My main reasons not to recommend it are:

1) The length. It's easily the shortest of the 3 main entries in the series. Even exploring as much as I could to find anything I could interact with, I got through it in a mere 4 hours. In fact, for most of the game I assumed I was playing through the prologue in order to have important context for the game proper. When I thought the real game was about to begin, the *twist* happened, and then roll credits.

2) The endless corridors. This is the main reason I assumed I was playing through a prologue when I was actually experiencing the bulk of this game's content. I recall environments to explore to find the important memories, and various things you could interact with in a few of the environments in the earlier games. The environments in this game are tiny, there is almost nothing to interact with, and it's literally just a series of rooms and corridors - often-repeating rooms and corridors, too. You don't even have to find anything - the memory orb things are just handed to you as you walk. There wasn't a huge amount of interactivity in the earlier games, but this one lacks it altogether and is a poorer experience for it.

3) The twist was bad and made it feel like this was an entirely pointless entry in the series. I won't spoil it for you, but it makes everything you experienced in the previous few hours utterly meaningless to the overall ongoing story begun in To the Moon. It. Was. So. Stupid. I already thought that the twist in Finding Paradise was contrived and just not-very-good, but not in a game-ruining sense. At least the idea of your journey revolving around a core memory was a good one. The twist in this one, however, made me almost angry. Such a slap in the face to the fans who waited eagerly for the next installment.

That's about it, really. They're charging the same amount, if I recall correctly, but you only get maybe 1/3 to 1/2 as much. And most, if not all, of it is rendered meaningless by a plot twist I never would have anticipated. We got the answers to a couple mysteries set up near the beginning of the game, and they were dumb.

To be honest, the story itself started interestingly, but got pretty strange - especially due to the involvement of previous characters. In my opinion, IF did not really wrap the trilogy up. Open questions from previous games were not really answered, but new questions arose. Though I sympathize with the underlying theme of the game, the way the story was told and the story itself did not catch me as much as TTM or FP.

For me, one of the reasons why the game did not feel so intriguing as the previous games was the music. The music of IF felt more like a remix of previously used music. To be honest, I was disappointed :-/ In my opinion, it is a shame that no song by Laura Shigihara was included. Her songs were what totally made me cry during the previous games. Straight to the heart in the strongest moment of the games. However, there was no song sung by her. Or any song sung by anyone. How can you not include a song in this game? (except for one in the credits ôo) The opportunities were there and suitable music would have catched me so much more, would have dragged me into the game. 

To be honest, IF felt so different overall and this feeling got stronger by the missing song. The music in general was not comparable to the music from the previous parts. 

To me, IF was more like a walking simulator. At times, I did not really know what to do and had to walk into every room, talk to everyone, go to every room again - hoping to hit the trigger to push the story forward. It felt exhausting at times. I did not like that feeling. I did not enjoy the game as much as I wished I would.

If there was a neutral option, I would chose it. But since Steam only allows a positive or negative review, I have to give a negative one, unfortunately. 
If you did not play TTM or FP then please do not play this game - I do not think you will understand much of the game.
And if you played TTM and FP then think twice before playing IF, because it might disappoint you if you expect too much.

PS: Please do not be confused by my "total play time" that Steam is showing for the game. I played most of the game when I had no internet connection and apparently, Steam does not take this time into account. I guess I played it for about 5 hours.

Although this isn't the reason I don't recommend it, I'm putting this at the top for those not familiar with the series: This is not a murder mystery, or a timeloop mystery, or a Lovecraftian horror story. The short description at the top of the page is a straight-up lie, and the content of the game is severely misrepresented by the screenshots. Do not play this without playing To The Moon and Finding Paradise. This is not a standalone game and you won't understand what's going on without that context.

As far as being a sequel to those games, this is why I don't recommend it. It's an okay, not great but passable, entry in the series and not nearly as good as the others. The pacing in particular is absolutely awful. The first 1/3 serves no purpose and is completely irrelevant to the story, the middle 1/3 is a looooooooooooooooong linear exposition segment with no exploration or interactivity that sets up the actual story, and the real story told in the last 1/3 is pretty decent. The whole thing could have been cut down to just the last 1/3 with occasional bits from the other 2/3 added for context and it would have been infinitely better.

That said, if you haven't played To The Moon or Finding Paradise, definitely go play those they're worth it.

A few people have mentioned this but Impostor Factory really does not feel as though it has a heart. Moreover, it feels like it has fallen into the fan-service trap you see with smalltime creators, webcomic artists etc... At some point when the (relatively short and needlessly sad) story is done and wrapped up, instead of developing on that story with proper gameplay at any step of the way, we are somehow tossed into an act three that is essentially the exposition and reference dump from hell. 
I am interested in TTM's meta-story, but you can't really get me invested in your main character dilemma without having meaningful character moments, and you can't then destroy all empathy I had built for these characters by making me feel like nothing I just witnessed mattered at all. 100996536.review:
Impostor Factory is the third story RPG maker game of the To the Moon series that changes up a lot of things and manages to be both a sequel and a prequel.

Lots of changes are introduced for this game. Instead of exploring and figuring out the story like in the previous games, here it feels like someone just takes us for a ride. It's a lot more linear, none of the puzzle or mini games. Changing the perspective of how the story is told makes it refreshing. It tries somehow new with a strong start of a murder mystery that fizzles out into the routinely emotional story that the series knows we expect. And while it's a good story, it's emotionally less hard hitting than the previous games. But in it's stead the meta plot of the doctors is explored more with giving some answers and leaving more questions. Overall this game is a bit too ambitious, but still decent that makes more sense if you played the previous games and feels like it's a great set up for the next game.

Controls are the standard found in RPGmaker games with the addition to play with the mouse. Playing the game feels like a walking simulator in RPGmaker form. A small windowed resolution is the best way to play through it as fullscreen can cause lots of issues. The quality of the visuals is noticeably higher from the previous games in the series and even they did stand out among RPGmaker games.

For achievement hunters:
The only achievement is for completing the game.

One thing to note, is the game features an impeccable story that is told throughout its games. Once you get emotionally attached to the characters, the saddest and happiest thing will follow.

100979376.review: This franchise means the most to me more than most in the world of video games. The intimate storytelling that Kan Gao and his team portrays with such limitation is unbelievable, and they deliver again a third time. While the story never hits the emotional gut punches or raw connection that the previous two dive into, Impostor Factory shows that Freebird Games still has a lot of creative ideas left in the world they've built, and I hope to continue to see more of it in any form that takes. The writing rides the impossible line from being laugh out loud funny to heartbreakingly grim, and from cheerful optimism to a thrilling sense of ominous mystery. Impostor Factory really nails its atmosphere, between the more linear storytelling and the ever-fantastic music. If you had any form of enjoyment playing the games that this company has made, please give them money to make more. This studio needs to continue creating some of the best art in the business, mostly so I have an excuse to cry a little shamelessly every so often.

Anyway... Please, support Freebird Games, and check out Impostor Factory. It's a rather short play, but the story is SO enjoyable. I don't cry from video games often, but this series has gotten me EVERY time.

100911739.review:
Let me begin the review by appreciating Kan Gao, the mastermind behind the entire trilogy. His name itself should be convincing enough to purchase the game.

Now getting back to Impostor Factory - HOLY SH#T! I cannot describe in words how good the game was. I could not have asked for a better sequel for To The Moon series. With Kan Gao the expectations are always high and it's safe to say he hasn't disappointed his followers, yet again.

+ Touching music, blends extremely well with the plot.
+ Beautiful art and cutscenes.
+ Heartwrenching storyline. Made very teary as the story progressed.

All in all, Impostor Factory was worth the wait after all those delays. I would wait for a perfectly polished game than a rushed game. Would strongly recommend everyone to buy it regardless of a sale!!

[b]PS: You do NEED to play To The Moon, Minisodes and Finding Paradise to understand the plot. It may say it's a standalone game but it really isn't, trust me. The story basically builds upon those two prequels.[/b]

100910615.review:
I'm an absolute fan of the series. To The Moon is one of my most beloved games ever, and Finding Paradise is somewhere close. Maybe my high expectations made me slightly disappointed, or maybe because this game went heavier into the narrative complexity and less into the personal mysteries, that might have made me less invested into it. It may sound harsh but it's only because the previous two games, and To The Moon in particular, hit me with such unbelievable strength that it becomes hard to replicate the impact.

It's a great game for those that appreciate the art and the narrative, not only cookie-cutter mechanics and formulas of so many AAA titles.

LONG REVIEW:
off the bat, I want to say this game is VERY unlike the other games. At least, the pacing/structure has been completely changed. You'll see what I mean. Just don't expect it to be the same as the other games; this is a good thing!

Next, as the other reviews have been saying, yes, the crazy emotional impact is a bit lower tier compared to the other two, bUT I have to argue that this game was the deepest and thought-provoking one compared to the other ones.

Less gameplay and more story driven, this is definitely a way to experiment new ways to storytell, and I think it was pretty successful! With all the crazy plot twists and the overarching story making more sense, this game was a necessary addition that will be enjoyed by many people who liked the previous games.

in conclusion, this game BETTER not be the last one in the series, or else carnage will ensue

EDIT: 
this game requires SOO MUCH big brain as well

100857996.review:
Impostor "Kan Gao te vuelve romper el corazón" Factory es el siguiente capítulo en la historia/universo de To the moon.
La diferencia en esta nueva entrega es que no estamos desde la perspectiva de los doctores si no que nos ubica en unos escenarios nuevos, con nuevos personajes y una trama que te impactará de primeras pero... wow.
Como de costumbre la banda sonora es increíblemente buena y con referencias y detalles de canciones de los anteriores juegos.
Lo difícil que es contar bien una historia y la manera en que este hombre lo hace es magistral y como maneja las emociones según las situaciones.
Yo diría que la historia es la "menos" triste de la saga pero si las más compleja.
Si habéis jugado todo lo anterior, necesitáis jugar este también, de verdad.
Al igual que el resto de juegos deja mensajes muy importantes y reflejos de la vida real para generar reflexión.
Y a diferencia de los anteriores no es tan interactivo, con esto me refiero a que no hay minijuegos de mementos ni mucho por explorar.
La duración es aproximada a Finding Paradise y To the Moon, relativamente corta pero un buen viaje emocional.
	
Otra obra maestra del estudio, deseando saber que será lo siguiente. Si continuará con el universo Sigmund Corp o será algo nuevo.
Porque incluso con esta historia quedan un par de preguntas en el aire...
PD: las capturas de steam con el F12 funcionan en este juego, que en los anteriores no podías hacer capturas.

100854873.review: AMAZING, Rollercoaster of a ride and your emotions, take out them tissues! 10/10, I love this developer and all the games they release. Looking forward to the next one ! :)

100853730.review:
This entry is definitely riding on the coattails of To The Moon and Finding Paradise. It's also clearly a sequel. Yeah, I guess you can play this game without having played the others, just like you can start watching The Two Towers without having seen Fellowship, but it won't make total sense. 

In my opinion, Finding Paradise is one of the greatest games ever made, so expectations were high.  

The series continue to explore the subject of the butterfly effect and how small or large decisions can have immense ripple effect in the future. The issue is the devs crammed a ton of topics (butterfly effect, parenthood, pursuit of greatness vs simple life, alternate timelines, etc) and genres (murder mystery, dramedy, sci-fi, love story, drama, slice of life...) into one narrative, and tying that together in a story that honestly makes no sense (did anyone actually understand the mess that was the 3rd act?). I really thought at the beginning of the second act that the focus of Simple Life VS Pursuit of Greatness would be the central theme, with the two leads tugging at each end. Instead, the writers canned that as soon as they could and moved on to some convoluted alternate, parallel reality plot that I am willing to bet $100 even Kan Gao does not understand. Bigger isn't always better. Freebird is known for taking common slice of life stories and diving deep into them, not sci-fi and half-azzed humor (the cat? the Pokemon reference made me chuckle but it was annoying fast. Ricebot is life though. Ricebot is love. ). 

And I had no idea Neil Watts was such a popular character to be shoehorned into this story which had nothing to do with him. I always thought Neil and Rosalene to be the game player's eyes in the prequels, not the main characters, so seeing them forced into a story about Lynri was just a poor attempt at fan service.

Definitely the weakest game, weaker than Bird Story. It may resonate with you if you're a parent maybe? Only play this is if you played the prequels and loved them.
